notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 5 - Russel's Reserve 13 Year - Spring 2025.md
notes.content:
### Initial Thoughts

Every time Russell‚Äôs 13 drops, expectations are sky high, and this batch delivers. It brings that classic Wild Turkey funk in spades. The nose pulls you in with funk and rich sweetness, and the first sip confirms it‚Äôs dialed in. It‚Äôs bold, balanced, and well aged without drifting into heavy oak. I‚Äôve heard and watched (YouTube) people say it‚Äôs not as strong as past releases, but I can only judge what‚Äôs in my glass, and it‚Äôs pretty darn good.
#### Glass: Glencairn - Rested for: 2 hours (went on a walk)

#### Proof: 123.8

#### Age: 13 Years old (youngest component)

#### Mashbill: 75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley

#### Appearance: Red Amber

## Nose
Classic Wild Turkey funk turned up a good notch. Rich caramel and brown sugar open up, backed by toasted walnut and nutmeg. Layers of oak char, cherry, and cinnamon add depth. Subtle hints of leather and tobacco linger underneath.

## Palate
The palate opens with a rush of cherries, followed by layers of caramel and brown sugar. Charred oak steps in next, bringing cinnamon and walnut and nutmeg before easing into a dry finish of leather, dark chocolate and tobacco. The proof feels spot on, balanced and cohesive, letting each note play its part without anything overpowering the rest.
## Finish
The finish is long and steady, carrying forward the oak, leather, and tobacco from the palate. A touch of dark chocolate and dry spice linger as the sweetness fades, leaving a warm, drying finish. Makes me want to sip again!

## Final Thoughts
This release hits a great balance of depth and drinkability. The oak, leather, and tobacco carry through without getting super bitter, and that touch of dark chocolate and spice ties it all together. It‚Äôs layered, consistent, and easy to come back to. Definitely one of those pours that keeps you reaching for another glass. Turkey fan boys should pick one up if they find it at msrp. I do have to say though, the price tag on this bottle is a bit too steep. Jack Daniel's 14 year is $149 MERP. Jim Beam‚Äôs Hardin‚Äôs Creek line, the 184 month and 211 month 15 & 17.5 year releases were below $175 MSRP..I'm not sure how WT justifies these succeedingly increasing prices. I paid MSRP for this bottle. I would not touch it at secondary prices.

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 8.8 Excellent, really quite exceptional

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn‚Äôt consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I‚Äôd rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect

![[IMG_0970.jpg]]

![[IMG_0971.jpg]]

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 4 - Bomberger's PFG 2024 Release.md
notes.content:
### Initial Thoughts
From the first pour, you can tell this Bomberger‚Äôs is something different. The French oak finish adds a smooth, rounded sweetness that hits before you even take a sip. Amaretto, maple-brown sugar, and a touch of candied orange, all wrapped in warm spice and seasoned oak. Knowing those barrels spent years air-drying by the Charente River makes sense once you taste it. There‚Äôs a calm, mature character that ties everything together. It‚Äôs rich, layered, and Bombergers-y.


#### Glass: Glencairn - Rested for: 30 minutes

#### Proof: 100.2

#### Age: NAS

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: Amber red

## Nose
The nose opens with a wave of amaretto and maple-brown sugar, followed by warm notes of sweet corn and candied orange peel. Layers of seasoned oak and worn leather ground the profile, while a lively mix of cinnamon, clove, allspice, and black pepper add a refined, spicy edge.

## Palate
The palate mirrors the nose beautifully. Amaretto leads the way, followed by waves of maple brown sugar and baking spice cinnamon, allspice, and a crack of black pepper. Leather and well seasoned oak round out the experience, giving structure and balance to the sweetness. Exceptionally cohesive and well balanced. 

## Finish
Drying, medium long finish ( ~25 seconds) of seasoned oak, leather, and lingering baking spice. Sweet traces of amaretto and maple are present before tapering into dry peppered oak. Great finish for a 100 proofer.

## Final Thoughts
This one hits all the right notes, sweet, spicy, oaky, and just plain satisfying. It feels classic and dusty but with a touch of polish that makes it special. A great example of what Bomberger‚Äôs does best.

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 7.8 Great, well above average

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn‚Äôt consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I‚Äôd rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 3 - Jack Daniel's Heritage Toasted Barrel.md
notes.content:
### Initial Thoughts
Being a JD fanboy, I was pretty excited to hear that Jack Daniel‚Äôs was releasing a regular shelf whiskey with a toasted profile and real age behind it, and it didn‚Äôt disappoint. This release uses the classic Tennessee Whiskey recipe but with **Heritage barrels** toasted twice as long before ( ~24 minutes I believe) a quick char. The whiskey enters at a lower **100 proof**, ages for **seven years** in hotter, higher warehouses, and is **non-chill filtered** before being bottled back at **100 proof**. The final product is a richer, more caramelized sweetness and deeper oak character than their standard lineup.


#### Glass: Glencairn - Rested for: 20 minutes

#### Proof: 100

#### Age: 8 years 2 months 6 days

#### Mashbill: 80% Corn, 12% Malted Barley, 8% Rye

#### Appearance: Dark amber

## Nose
Bubblegum, brown sugar, vanilla, toasted marshmallow. Spiced with black pepper and nutmeg, then grounded by leather and charred oak. A hint of caramelized banana is apparent when you dig for it. It's pure liquid dessert.

## Palate
Rich waves of **toasted marshmallow** dipped in **brown sugar**, finished with a silky **vanilla cream drizzle**. Intensely sweet and dessert like, but still well balanced. The **banana** fades here, but its absence doesn‚Äôt detract from the decadent character.

## Finish
A warm surge post swallow that melts into **maple-drizzled brown sugar** and soft char. Short to medium about 15 seconds, which feels right for 100 proof.

## Final Thoughts
My first reaction was, thank goodness I grabbed a backup. Jack Daniel‚Äôs is putting out some seriously quality juice here. I‚Äôd love to see this at a higher proof, though that might push it into Coy Hill territory. The Heritage Barrel Toasted reminds me of the Jack Daniel‚Äôs 12 Year, sharing similar oak depth and sweet notes, but with far less banana. If you spot a bottle, it‚Äôs absolutely worth picking up.

## Rating (t8ke scale)
## 8.2 Really quite exceptional

1 | Disgusting | So bad I poured it out

2 | Poor | I wouldn‚Äôt consume by choice

3 | Bad | Multiple flaws

4 | Sub-par | Not bad, but many things I‚Äôd rather have

5 | Good | Good, just fine

6 | Very Good | A cut above

7 | Great | Well above average

8 | Excellent | Really quite exceptional

9 | Incredible | An all-time favorite

10 | Perfect | Perfect

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Whiskey Reviews/Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month.md
notes.content:
#### Glass: Glencairn - rested for 1h

#### 184mo Proof : 108 (54% ABV)

#### 211mo Proof: 109 (54.5% ABV)

#### 185mo Age: 15 & 16 year old blend

#### 211mo Age:  17.58 years old (youngest component)

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: The 211 month is a shade darker in proper lighting. The pictures might not do justice regarding color accuracy. Nonetheless, I would have expected these to be a tad darker for their age statements. 

I am fortunate enough to have found these bottles at acceptable secondary pricesa while back. I paid $230 for each 184 month, $260 for each of the 211's. These Jim Beam releases have flown under the radar, and after reading @u/vexmythocrut‚Äôs review today, I was reminded that I should get doing what I said I would do: review the 184 & 211 month HC's side by side. This has been a great review to write, knowing that these two are my #1 and #2 bottles in my collection. For context, here are the supposed mashbills:

### **Jacob‚Äôs Well 184-month**
- Blend of:
    - **High-rye bourbon mashbill** (78% corn, 12% rye, 10% malted barley) aged 15 years
    - **Traditional bourbon mashbill** (75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley) aged 16 years
### **Jacob‚Äôs Well 211-month**
- Blend of:
    - **High-rye bourbon mashbill** (78% corn, 12% rye, 10% malted barley) aged 17 years and 7 months
    - **Traditional bourbon mashbill** (75% corn, 13% rye, 12% malted barley) aged 17 years and 7 months

### 184 Month:
## Nose
The nose on this has opened up from the last time I remember. A cherry cola/caramel note hits me right up front, which weirdly I didn‚Äôt get the first go around ‚Äî maybe reading @u/vexmythocrut‚Äôs review of the 184mo today influenced me. Next comes a deep, rich raspberry/[[Review 1 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month|cherry compote]] wrapped in well-[[Review 1 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month|aged oak]], consistent with my last review. I‚Äôll reiterate from my initial notes: it‚Äôs still got that marzipan note I really enjoy. To round it off, there‚Äôs freshly ground black pepper, tobacco leaf, full-grain leather, and a bit of rye spice wrapped in a blanket of well-aged oak.

## Palate
From my last post, still stands: Well aged oak right off the bat, then a wave of deep dark brown sugar glaze on a thin wafer of well [[Review 1 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month|seasoned oak]]. You get that deep rich oak character. Then on the mid-palate I get notes of [[Review 1 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month|star anise]] and light clove as well as a sweet dark plum, dates, nutmeg and raisins. There is absolutley nothing sharp about this pour, it is balanced and the age really mellows it out on the palate. Imagine a graceful samurai, precise and controlled, striking with elegance rather than force. That‚Äôs this bourbon.. layered, patient, and confident without needing to shout.

## Finish
I stand by what I have written before in my previous review: The finish is lingering, but not too extended, a characteristic I would attribute to a much higher proof offering. But with that, it's still very pleasant. On the back end, the seasoned oak comes through alongside subtle notes of clove and star anise. There‚Äôs also a fleeting hint of fruit, like licking the spoon you used to stir a raspberry/cherry compote, warm, spiced, and faintly sweet.

### 211 Month:
## Nose
First thing I notice is that the ethanol is a bit subdued on the 211 compared to the 184, which is typical of higher age stated bourbons. The next scent I am hit with is a giant wave of expertly aged oak, followed by the same cherry cola note that's present on the 184 month. I am getting more fresh black pepper here, more leather, allspice, nutmeg, a bit of clove, and stewed figs, all harmoniously coming together like freshly baked cherry spice cake infused with warm nutmeg, clove, and allspice, topped with rich dried figs, and served beside a drizzle of pepper-infused caramel. The bouquet on this pour is amazing.

## Palate
Viscous, oily, and silky smooth. The mid-palate unfolds with layers of nuanced oak, followed by a rich cherry cola jam spread over a graham cracker, accented by freshly ground black pepper, nutmeg, clove, allspice, and a touch of molasses drizzle. If I were to relate the 211 month to a figure, they would be elegant, bold, and deeply layered, a gentleman of many stories.

## Finish
Finish is a tad bit longer than the 184mo, but truthfully, I'm spliting hairs here. There is a star anise note on this that I really enjoy, it lasts longer than the 184 mo. I also pick up a bit more leather and tobacco, which adds a pleasant richness. The finish is not too drying but you notice the oak tannins leaving your tounge a little parched, a quality that, to me, only adds character.

### Thoughts
This comparison llustrates how those extra 2-3 years transform a bourbon. While the 184-month shows elegance and balance, the 211-month demonstrates what patience can achieve. That subdued ethanol, enhanced viscosity, and deeper oak integration suggest a whiskey that's reached a different level of maturity. Considerign value, if you can get these at msrp, and given their age statements, these Hardin's Creek releases are on the premium end of the spectrum. The question becomes whether the marginal improvements in the 211-month (slightly longer finish, more integrated nose, silkier mouthfeel) justify what's likely a significant price premium. For collectors, probably yes. For drinkers, it might depend on the actual price delta.

As a last note, these are bottles that demand contemplation, not consumption. The kind you pour for those who can appreciate the decades of patience in each glass. Thank you for reading!!

### 184 month

notes.content:
![[IMG_7008.jpeg]]


![[IMG_7012.jpeg]]

![[IMG_7015.jpeg]]

![[ChatGPT Image May 18, 2025, 07_52_10 PM.png]]

Hey all! Loooong time lurker here, and as you can see from the title, this is my first ever review. I never thought I would write a review, but that's before I had the great pleasure of having a couple of pours of Jim Beam's (yes it's a Jim Beam product) Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 month aged bourbon. This offering from Beam is incorporates 15y and 16y aged whiskey from two mashbills both from JB. Part the HC -JW 184mo whiskey comes from the mashbill from JB's main offerings of Jim Beam, Knob Creek, and Bookers. The other blended whiskey comes from the high rye mashbill of the Old Grand Dad line.


#### Glass: Glencairn - rested for 1h

#### Proof: 108 (54% ABV)

#### Age: 15 & 16 year old blend

#### Mashbill: Undisclosed

#### Appearance: Not as dark as I would have expected for a 15y+ product but still asemi-dark rich amber color.

## Nose
The first scent i get on the nose is a deep and rich raspberry/[[Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month|cherry compote]] wrapped in well [[Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month|aged oak]]. One thing this nose reminds me of is a toasted bearclaw pastry that's filled with almond paste or marzipan. But image it coming out of a toaster oven, where you get that burnt sugar smell/marzipan smell...just heavenly. Digging deep in the nose I get some [[Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month|star anise]] and I a faint hint of the rye spice. 

## Palate
Well aged oak right off the bat, then a wave of deep dark brown sugar glaze on a thin wafer of well [[Review 2 - Hardin's Creek Jacob's Well 184 & 211 month|seasoned oak]]. You get that deep rich oak character. Then on the mid-palate I get notes of star anise and light clove as well as a sweet dark plum, dates, nutmeg and raisins. There is absolutley nothing sharp about this pour, it is balanced and the age really mellows it out on the palate. Imagine a graceful samurai, precise and controlled, striking with elegance rather than force. That‚Äôs this bourbon.. layered, patient, and confident without needing to shout.

## Finish
The finish is lingering, but not too extended, a characteristic I would attribute to a much higher proof offering. But with that, it's still very pleasant. On the back end, the seasoned oak comes through alongside subtle notes of clove and star anise. There‚Äôs also a fleeting hint of fruit, like licking the spoon you used to stir a raspberry/cherry compote, warm, spiced, and faintly sweet.

## Thoughts
Like I said, I've been contempt with lingering around this subreddit for sometime but I have never gotten the urge to write a post until this whiskey graced my lips. It is such a well made bourbon that I felt compelled enough to tell you guys/gals about it. Anywho, after I had the first couple pours of this, I went to my local liquor store and bought the backup of this bottle. I couldn't resist the urge. I am really curious as to how the HC Jacob's Well batch 2 - 211 month stacks up against this. I will have to blind them down the road. I would be amazed if it is THAT much better. Thanks for reading. Cheers! üçª

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive Security Engineer/Tests/OFFSEC Study Guide - Google AI Studio.md
notes.content:
Okay, this is exciting! An Offensive Security Engineer role at a top tech company means they'll expect deep technical knowledge, a strong offensive mindset, and the ability to articulate complex concepts clearly. The focus on "Network Infrastructure" and "Web App" is a solid foundation.

Here's an in-depth study guide tailored for you.

**Overall Mindset for the Interview:**

*   **Think Like an Attacker:** For every technology, protocol, or application, ask:
    *   How can this be misconfigured?
    *   What are its known vulnerabilities?
    *   How can I abuse its intended functionality?
    *   How would I enumerate/discover this?
    *   How would I gain a foothold?
    *   How would I escalate privileges?
    *   How would I move laterally?
    *   How would I exfiltrate data?
    *   How would I maintain persistence?
    *   How would I evade detection?
*   **Methodology is Key:** Be ready to explain your process for tackling a new target (network or web app). Mention frameworks like PTES (Penetration Testing Execution Standard) or your own structured approach.
*   **Hands-on Experience:** Be prepared to discuss *your* experience finding vulnerabilities, not just theoretical knowledge. If you have personal projects, CTF experience (HackTheBox, TryHackMe), or bug bounty finds, highlight them.
*   **Communication:** Clearly explain technical concepts. They want to see if you can convey risk and technical details to different audiences.
*   **Be Honest:** If you don't know something, say so, but perhaps offer how you would go about finding the answer.

---

**I. Network Infrastructure Security (Offensive Perspective)**

This area covers everything from the physical layer (less likely to be tested in detail for this role unless it's very specialized) up to the services running on hosts.

**A. Reconnaissance & Enumeration (The Foundation)**
    *   **OSINT (Open Source Intelligence):**
        *   Techniques: Google dorking, Shodan, Censys, social media, public code repositories (GitHub), domain/subdomain enumeration tools (Amass, Sublist3r, Assetfinder), certificate transparency logs.
        *   Purpose: Discovering external footprint, technologies used, employee information, potential attack vectors.
        *   *Potential Question:* "Describe your process for initial reconnaissance against a corporate network."
    *   **Active Scanning & Enumeration:**
        *   **Nmap (Crucial):**
            *   Scan types: SYN (stealth), TCP Connect, UDP, Version, OS detection, Scripting Engine (NSE).
            *   Flags: `-sS, -sT, -sU, -sV, -O, -A, -p-, -Pn, -n, --script`.
            *   Know how to interpret Nmap output and identify interesting ports/services.
            *   *Potential Question:* "You run an Nmap scan and find port X open. What are your next steps?"
        *   **Service-Specific Enumeration:**
            *   **SMB/CIFS (Ports 139, 445):** `enum4linux`, `smbclient`, `nmap smb-nse-scripts`. Looking for shares, users, OS info.
            *   **NFS (Port 2049):** `showmount -e <IP>`, mounting shares.
            *   **DNS (Port 53):** Zone transfers (`dig axfr @<dns_server> <domain>`), subdomain brute-forcing (`dnsrecon`), cache snooping.
            *   **SMTP (Port 25):** `VRFY`, `EXPN` (often disabled).
            *   **SNMP (Port 161):** Default community strings (public, private), `snmpwalk`, `snmp-check`.
            *   **LDAP (Port 389, 636):** Anonymous binds, `ldapsearch`, `nmap ldap-nse-scripts`.
            *   **RPC (Port 135):** `rpcinfo`, `rpcdump`.
            *   **SSH (Port 22):** Banner grabbing, username enumeration (timing attacks - less common now).
            *   **FTP (Port 21):** Anonymous login, banner grabbing.
            *   **HTTP/S (Ports 80, 443):** Covered more in Web App, but initial dir busting (`dirb`, `gobuster`, `ffuf`), technology identification (`whatweb`, Wappalyzer).
        *   *Potential Question:* "How would you enumerate services on a Windows host versus a Linux host once you have initial port scan results?"

**B. Common Network Protocols & Their Vulnerabilities**
    *   **TCP/IP Suite:**
        *   Understand the 3-way handshake.
        *   ARP Spoofing / Poisoning (MITM).
        *   IP Spoofing.
        *   TCP Session Hijacking.
    *   **DNS:** Cache poisoning, zone transfers, amplification attacks (DDoS).
    *   **DHCP:** Rogue DHCP server, DHCP starvation.
    *   **HTTP/HTTPS:** Covered in Web App.
    *   **SSL/TLS:** Weak ciphers, certificate issues, POODLE, Heartbleed (older but good to know concepts).
    *   **VPNs (IPSec, OpenVPN, SSL VPNs):** Misconfigurations, weak pre-shared keys, vulnerable client software.
    *   **Routing Protocols (OSPF, BGP, EIGRP):** Authentication weaknesses, route injection (more advanced, but good awareness).
    *   **IPv6:** Misconfigurations, rogue RAs, NDP attacks. Often an overlooked attack surface.

**C. Exploitation & Post-Exploitation (Network Focus)**
    *   **Exploiting Misconfigurations:**
        *   Default credentials on services (routers, switches, printers, applications).
        *   Unnecessary services enabled.
        *   Weak ACLs/firewall rules.
        *   Open file shares with sensitive data or write access.
    *   **Exploiting Known Vulnerabilities:**
        *   Using Metasploit Framework: `search`, `use`, `set payload`, `exploit`, `sessions`.
        *   Manual exploitation: Understanding buffer overflows (stack, heap - conceptual understanding is usually enough), RCEs.
        *   Patch management gaps.
        *   *Potential Question:* "You find a specific version of Apache running on a server. How do you determine if it's vulnerable and proceed?"
    *   **Privilege Escalation (OS Level):**
        *   **Linux:** SUID/GUID binaries, cron jobs, kernel exploits, sudo misconfigurations, weak file permissions. Tools: `LinEnum.sh`, `linuxprivchecker.py`, `GTFOBins`.
        *   **Windows:** Unquoted service paths, DLL hijacking, insecure service permissions, AlwaysInstallElevated, kernel exploits, token impersonation/theft. Tools: `PowerUp.ps1`, `Sherlock.ps1`, `Seatbelt.exe`, `WinPEAS`.
    *   **Lateral Movement:**
        *   Pass-the-Hash (PtH), Pass-the-Ticket (PtT) - Kerberos.
        *   Exploiting trust relationships.
        *   Using compromised credentials on other systems (SSH, RDP, WinRM).
        *   Pivoting: Creating tunnels (SSH, `chisel`, `ligolo-ng`) to access internal networks.
        *   *Potential Question:* "You've compromised a DMZ web server. How would you attempt to move into the internal corporate network?"
    *   **Persistence:**
        *   Cron jobs, scheduled tasks, services, registry keys (Windows), backdoored binaries.
    *   **Data Exfiltration:**
        *   DNS tunneling, ICMP tunneling, HTTP/S, FTP.
        *   Covert channels.
    *   **Evasion:**
        *   Firewall/IDS/IPS evasion techniques (fragmentation, encoding, polymorphic shellcode).
        *   AV Evasion (obfuscation, packers, custom shellcode).
        *   Log tampering/clearing (less common to admit to, but know the techniques).

**D. Active Directory & Windows Environments (Often a Huge Part of Corp Networks)**
    *   **Recon/Enumeration:**
        *   `BloodHound` (critical for AD recon: users, groups, computers, OUs, GPOs, ACLs, attack paths).
        *   `PowerView` (PowerShell tool for AD enumeration).
        *   LDAP queries.
    *   **Common Attacks:**
        *   Kerberoasting (cracking service account TGS tickets).
        *   AS-REP Roasting (cracking TGTs for users with Kerberos pre-auth disabled).
        *   LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay (Responder, ntlmrelayx).
        *   Password Spraying.
        *   Golden Ticket / Silver Ticket attacks (Mimikatz).
        *   DCSync.
        *   Group Policy Object (GPO) abuse.
        *   Unconstrained/Constrained Delegation abuse.
    *   *Potential Question:* "Describe common attack paths within an Active Directory environment."

**E. Cloud Networking (AWS, Azure, GCP - Focus on Concepts if not specific platform)**
    *   **Misconfigurations:**
        *   Public S3 buckets / Azure Blobs / GCP Storage.
        *   Overly permissive Security Groups / Network Security Groups (NSGs).
        *   Exposed instance metadata services (IMDS).
        *   Weak IAM policies/roles.
    *   **Attack Vectors:**
        *   Compromised credentials (API keys, access keys).
        *   SSRF to pivot to cloud services.
        *   Vulnerable serverless functions.
    *   *Potential Question:* "What are some common security misconfigurations you look for in an AWS environment?"

**F. Wireless Networks**
    *   WPA2/3-PSK (cracking handshakes - aircrack-ng).
    *   WPA2/3-Enterprise (RADIUS misconfigurations, EAP vulnerabilities).
    *   Rogue Access Points.
    *   Evil Twin attacks.

**G. Network Security Devices**
    *   **Firewalls:** Stateful vs. Stateless, NGFW. Understanding rule sets, common bypass techniques.
    *   **IDS/IPS:** Signature-based vs. Anomaly-based. Evasion techniques.
    *   **WAFs:** How they work, common bypasses (encoding, character sets, etc.).
    *   **Proxies:** Forward vs. Reverse. How they can be abused or used for pivoting.

---

**II. Web Application Security (Offensive Perspective)**

This will likely be a deep dive. The OWASP Top 10 is your bible here.

**A. The OWASP Top 10 (Current Version - know it inside out)**
    *   For each, understand:
        *   What is it?
        *   How to find it (manual and automated techniques).
        *   How to exploit it.
        *   Impact.
        *   Basic remediation (though you're offensive, knowing this shows understanding).
    *   **A01:2021 ‚Äì Broken Access Control:**
        *   Horizontal/Vertical privilege escalation, Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR), path traversal via access control misconfigs.
        *   *Example:* Changing a user ID in a URL (`/user/123/profile` to `/user/124/profile`) to access another user's data.
    *   **A02:2021 ‚Äì Cryptographic Failures:**
        *   Sensitive data exposure (in transit or at rest), weak crypto algorithms, default keys, no HSTS.
        *   *Example:* Passwords stored in plaintext or using MD5.
    *   **A03:2021 ‚Äì Injection:**
        *   SQL Injection (SQLi): Union-based, error-based, blind (boolean, time-based). Tools: `sqlmap`.
        *   NoSQL Injection.
        *   OS Command Injection.
        *   LDAP Injection.
        *   XPath Injection.
        *   *Potential Question:* "Explain the difference between in-band and out-of-band SQL injection and how you'd test for them."
    *   **A04:2021 ‚Äì Insecure Design:**
        *   Focuses on flaws in business logic, design patterns that lack security controls from the start.
        *   *Example:* A password reset flow that doesn't adequately verify the user's identity.
    *   **A05:2021 ‚Äì Security Misconfiguration:**
        *   Default credentials, unnecessary features enabled (e.g., DEBUG mode), directory listing, verbose error messages, improper HTTP headers.
        *   *Example:* An S3 bucket with public read/write that stores user uploads.
    *   **A06:2021 ‚Äì Vulnerable and Outdated Components:**
        *   Using libraries, frameworks, or other software modules with known vulnerabilities.
        *   *Example:* Using an old version of jQuery with a known XSS vulnerability.
    *   **A07:2021 ‚Äì Identification and Authentication Failures:**
        *   Weak password policies, session fixation, credential stuffing, missing MFA, session timeout issues.
        *   *Example:* A session token that never expires.
    *   **A08:2021 ‚Äì Software and Data Integrity Failures:**
        *   Insecure Deserialization, software updates without validation, CI/CD pipeline compromises.
        *   *Example:* A Java application deserializing untrusted user input leading to RCE.
    *   **A09:2021 ‚Äì Security Logging and Monitoring Failures:**
        *   Lack of adequate logging, inability to detect or respond to breaches.
        *   *From an offensive PoV:* How this makes your attacks easier.
    *   **A10:2021 ‚Äì Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF):**
        *   Forcing the server to make requests to internal or external resources.
        *   Can be used to scan internal networks, access cloud metadata services, interact with internal services.
        *   *Potential Question:* "How can SSRF be used to pivot within a cloud environment like AWS?"

**B. Other Key Web App Vulnerabilities**
    *   **Cross-Site Scripting (XSS):**
        *   Reflected, Stored, DOM-based.
        *   Payloads: `<script>alert(1)</script>`, stealing cookies, keylogging, redirecting.
        *   Bypassing WAFs/filters.
        *   *Potential Question:* "Describe the difference between Stored and Reflected XSS and provide an example of how you'd exploit each."
    *   **Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF):**
        *   Forcing a logged-in user's browser to send a forged HTTP request to a vulnerable web application.
        *   Requires understanding of anti-CSRF tokens and how to bypass them (if possible).
    *   **XML External Entity (XXE) Injection:**
        *   Exploiting XML parsers that process external entities.
        *   Can lead to file disclosure, SSRF, DoS.
    *   **HTTP Verb Tampering / Parameter Pollution.**
    *   **Business Logic Flaws:**
        *   Often unique to the application. Requires understanding how the app *should* work vs. how it *does* work.
        *   *Example:* Manipulating prices in a shopping cart, bypassing multi-step processes.
    *   **File Upload Vulnerabilities:**
        *   Uploading web shells (PHP, ASP, JSP), bypassing extension filters, content-type validation.
    *   **WebSockets / WebRTC Security.**
    *   **GraphQL / REST API Security (OWASP API Security Top 10 is relevant here):**
        *   Excessive Data Exposure.
        *   Broken Object Level Authorization (BOLA) / Broken Function Level Authorization (BFLA).
        *   Mass Assignment.
        *   Improper Assets Management / API versioning.
        *   Rate limiting and resource limiting issues.

**C. Web App Recon & Methodology**
    *   **Mapping the Application:**
        *   Spidering, directory/file brute-forcing (`dirb`, `gobuster`, `ffuf`, Burp Content Discovery).
        *   Identifying technologies used (`WhatWeb`, Wappalyzer, browser dev tools, HTTP headers).
        *   Understanding authentication/authorization mechanisms.
        *   Identifying input points (URL parameters, POST data, HTTP headers, cookies).
    *   **Tooling (Be proficient with at least one):**
        *   **Burp Suite (Professional is industry standard):** Intercepting proxy, Repeater, Intruder, Scanner, Decoder, Sequencer. Know these modules.
        *   OWASP ZAP (Free alternative).
        *   Browser Developer Tools (Inspect Element, Network tab, Console, Storage).
        *   Postman / REST clients for API testing.
    *   *Potential Question:* "Walk me through your methodology for testing a new web application you've never seen before."

**D. Authentication & Session Management**
    *   Cookies (attributes: HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite).
    *   JWT (JSON Web Tokens): Common vulnerabilities (alg=none, weak secrets, signature stripping).
    *   OAuth / OpenID Connect: Misconfigurations, redirect URI vulnerabilities.
    *   SAML.

---

**III. General Offensive Security & Interview Skills**

*   **Scripting:**
    *   Python is king for pentesters. Be able to write simple scripts for automation, parsing, or custom exploits.
    *   Bash scripting for quick tasks.
    *   PowerShell for Windows environments.
    *   *Potential Question:* "Describe a time you automated a penetration testing task with a script."
*   **Reporting:**
    *   How do you document vulnerabilities? (Severity, impact, likelihood, PoC, remediation).
    *   Ability to communicate technical risk to non-technical people.
*   **Evasion Techniques (Conceptual Understanding):**
    *   How do firewalls, IDS/IPS, WAFs, and EDR work at a high level?
    *   How can they be bypassed? (Fragmentation, obfuscation, encoding, living-off-the-land binaries - LOLBAS).
*   **Cryptography Basics:**
    *   Symmetric vs. Asymmetric encryption.
    *   Hashing.
    *   Digital Signatures.
    *   Common algorithms (AES, RSA, SHA-256).
    *   Understand *why* certain crypto is weak (e.g., MD5 for passwords).
*   **Operating Systems Internals (Basics):**
    *   Processes, memory management, file systems, permissions (Linux & Windows).
*   **Problem Solving:**
    *   They might give you a scenario: "You have X, Y, and Z. How do you achieve [goal]?" Break it down logically.
*   **Keeping Up-to-Date:**
    *   How do you stay current with new vulnerabilities, tools, and techniques? (Twitter, blogs, conferences, research papers, CVE lists).
*   **Ethical Considerations:**
    *   Understanding scope, rules of engagement, and legal boundaries.

---

**IV. Behavioral & Scenario Questions**

*   "Tell me about a time you found a critical vulnerability." (Use STAR method: Situation, Task, Action, Result).
*   "Describe a complex penetration test you were involved in."
*   "How do you handle disagreements with a client/developer about a vulnerability's severity?"
*   "What's a vulnerability you find particularly interesting and why?"
*   "Imagine you have shell access to a Linux server. What are the first few things you do to enumerate it for privilege escalation?"
*   "You suspect a web application is vulnerable to SQL injection, but WAF is blocking your attempts. What do you do?"
*   "If you could only use three tools for a network pentest, what would they be and why?"
*   "What are you passionate about in cybersecurity?"

---

**V. Preparation Strategy**

1.  **Prioritize:** Identify your weakest areas from the list above and focus there first.
2.  **Hands-on Labs:**
    *   **Hack The Box, TryHackMe, VulnHub:** Essential for practical experience. Focus on boxes that align with the topics (e.g., AD boxes, web app challenges).
    *   **PortSwigger Web Security Academy:** THE BEST resource for web app security. Do their labs.
3.  **Read Exploit Write-ups:** Understand the thought process of others.
4.  **Mock Interviews:** Practice explaining concepts out loud. If you can, get someone technical to ask you questions.
5.  **Review Your Own Experiences:** Think about projects, CTFs, or work where you've applied these skills. Prepare to talk about them.
6.  **Research the Company:** Understand their tech stack if possible ([[Job Descriptions]], tech blogs, employee LinkedIn profiles can give clues). This might hint at specific technologies they use.
7.  **Prepare Questions for Them:** Shows engagement and interest.
    *   "What does a typical day/week look like for an Offensive Security Engineer here?"
    *   "What are some of the biggest security challenges the team is currently focused on?"
    *   "How does the offensive security team collaborate with blue teams/development teams?"
    *   "What opportunities are there for research or tool development?"

---

This is a lot, but an "extremely reputable tech company" will have high expectations. Break it down, study consistently, and focus on understanding the *why* behind attacks, not just memorizing commands.

Good luck! You've got this!

# üõ° Offensive Security Engineer Interview Study Guide
**Focus:** Network Infrastructure | Web Application Security | Threat Emulation

---

## üîê 1. Network Infrastructure Security

### üß± Architecture & Segmentation
- Understand **conceptual**, **logical**, and **physical** network layers
- 
- Tiered network design: Public ‚Üí DMZ ‚Üí Middle Tier ‚Üí Internal
	- Public network: Open internet access, bots, attackers, etc...
	- DMZ: Publicly accessible data for website, webservers, email servers, dns, etc...
	- Middle Tier: Middleware, proxies, api gateways, identity services
	- Internal: PII servers, DB servers, sql/nosql servers, crown jewels
	
- Segmentation techniques: VLANs, SDN, air-gapping, internal firewalls
	- Virtual LANs can be implemented via router or layer 3 switch
	- 

### üö® Attacks Against Network Devices
**Routers:**
- DoS / DDoS
- Packet sniffing
- Routing table poisoning

**Switches:**
- MAC flooding
- VLAN hopping
- CDP/LLDP data leaks
- STP manipulation

### üì° Protocol Mastery (OSI + TCP/IP)
- Layers 1‚Äì4 (especially Layer 2‚Äì3 for exploitation)
- Focus protocols: IP, ICMP, TCP, UDP, DNS, DHCP
- Dissect traffic using `Wireshark`, `tcpdump`, `TShark`

### üîç Monitoring & Detection
- Placement of IDS/IPS (e.g. Snort, Suricata)

---

## üåê 2. Web Application Security

### üï∏ HTTP Fundamentals

- Cookie/session/token handling

### üö® Common Web Vulns (OWASP Top 10)

- Broken Authentication
- Insecure Deserialization
- CSRF
- Security Misconfiguration
- Sensitive Data Exposure

### üîß Tools
- `Burp Suite`, `ZAP Proxy`, `sqlmap`, `ffuf`, `gobuster`

### üîê Defenses to Know
- Input validation / Output encoding
- Proper cookie flags: `Secure`, `HttpOnly`, `SameSite`

---

## üõ†Ô∏è 3. Penetration Testing Methodology

### üß± Methodologies
- PTES: https://www.pentest-standard.org/
- OSSTMM, NIST SP 800-115, OWASP Testing Guide

### üß≠ Process Steps
1. Planning & Scoping
2. Reconnaissance
3. Vulnerability Scanning / Enumeration
4. Exploitation
5. Post-Exploitation
6. Reporting

### üîß Core Tools

- `Metasploit`, `Cobalt Strike`, `Empire`

## üß† 4. Vulnerability Management

---

## üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 5. Red Teaming & Threat Emulation

### ‚öî Kill Chain / MITRE ATT&CK
- Recon ‚Üí Delivery ‚Üí Exploitation ‚Üí C2 ‚Üí Exfiltration

### üéØ Purple Team Tactics

## üß™ Suggested Lab Practice Areas

## üìö Recommended Resources

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive Security Engineer/01 - Network Infra - Web App/OSI - TCPIP.md
notes.content:
### OSI Model

The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual framework that standardizes network communication functions into seven distinct layers:

1. **Physical Layer**: Transmits raw bit stream over physical medium (cables, wireless)
2. **Data Link Layer**: Provides node-to-node data transfer and error detection (MAC, LLC)
3. **[[Network Layer (Layer 3)|Network Layer]]**: Handles packet routing between networks (IP)
4. **[[Transport Layer (Layer 4)|Transport Layer]]**: Ensures complete data transfer and connection management (TCP, UDP)
5. **Session Layer**: Establishes, manages, and terminates connections
6. **Presentation Layer**: Translates data between application and network formats (encryption, compression)
7. **[[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|Application Layer]]**: Provides network services directly to end-users (HTTP, FTP, SMTP)

### TCP/IP Model

The TCP/IP model is a simplified, practical implementation of networking principles with four layers:

1. **Network Interface Layer**: Handles physical connection and hardware addressing (similar to OSI's Physical and Data Link layers)
2. **Internet Layer**: Manages logical addressing and routing between networks (IP protocol, equivalent to OSI's Network layer)
3. **Transport Layer**: Provides end-to-end communication and reliability (TCP/UDP, equivalent to OSI's Transport layer)
4. **Application Layer**: Combines OSI's Session, Presentation, and Application layers to handle user interfaces and applications (HTTP, FTP, DNS, SMTP)
    

Unlike the theoretical [[OSI Model]], TCP/IP was developed for practical implementation and forms the foundation of today's internet communications.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive Security Engineer/00 - Threat Emulation - Purple Team/Red Teaming VS. PenTesting.md
notes.content:
The key difference between **Red Teaming** and **Penetration Testing** lies in their **goals, scope, and approach**:

---

### üîç **Penetration Testing (Pentesting)**

**Goal**: Find as many vulnerabilities as possible in a system and report them.

**Characteristics**:

- **Broad coverage**: Tests many systems or applications for common weaknesses.
    
- **Short duration**: Typically 1‚Äì2 weeks.
    
- **Known engagement**: The blue team (defenders) is usually aware it's happening.
    
- **Checklist-driven**: Often follows standards like OWASP Top 10, NIST, or PTES.
    
- **Examples**:
    
    - Scanning a web app for SQLi or XSS.
        
    - Testing a VPN gateway for weak authentication.
        

---

### üéØ **Red Teaming**

**Goal**: Emulate a real-world attacker to test the detection and response capabilities of the organization.

**Characteristics**:

- **Narrow but deep**: Focuses on stealth, persistence, and objective-based missions (e.g., gain access to sensitive data).
    
- **Longer duration**: Can span weeks or months.
    
- **Covert**: The blue team usually isn‚Äôt told, to simulate a real intrusion.
    
- **TTP-based**: Uses tactics, techniques, and procedures from real threat actors (e.g., [[MITRE ATT&CK]] mapping).
    
- **Examples**:
    
    - Phishing an employee, then pivoting internally to steal data undetected.
        
    - Simulating APT-style intrusions using custom malware and evasion.
        

---

### üß† Summary Table

|Feature|Penetration Testing|Red Teaming|
|---|---|---|
|**Goal**|Identify vulnerabilities|Test detection & response to real threats|
|**Approach**|Vulnerability-focused|Adversary simulation|
|**Scope**|Wide and shallow|Narrow and deep|
|**Blue Team Aware?**|Usually yes|Usually no (stealth operation)|
|**Timeframe**|Days to weeks|Weeks to months|
|**Output**|Vulnerability report|Narrative + risk-focused report|

---

Would you like a sample real-world scenario comparing both side-by-side?

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive Security Engineer/00 - Threat Emulation - Purple Team/Red - Purple Team Threat Emulation.md
notes.content:
# Red & Purple Team Threat Emulation Knowledge Pack

## I. Planning & Threat Modeling

### What is threat emulation and how is it different from penetration testing?
- Threat emulation simulates a real adversary‚Äôs TTPs across the full kill chain.
- Focus is on realism, persistence, stealth, and achieving objectives.
- Penetration testing usually targets vulnerabilities and reports findings; threat emulation is broader and often without immediate remediation goals.

### How do you model an adversary?
- Choose based on:
  - Industry relevance (e.g., APT29 for gov, APT37 or FIN7 for financial).
  - Threat intel from Mandiant, CISA, CTI providers.
- Map their TTPs using [[MITRE ATT&CK]] or custom kill chains.
- Use VECTR or SCYTHE for adversary emulation planning.

### What frameworks do you use to guide emulation?
- [[MITRE ATT&CK]] ‚Äì TTP catalog and mapping.
- Cyber Kill Chain ‚Äì Structured attack lifecycle.
- NIST 800-53 / CSF ‚Äì Helps align with controls during purple teaming.
- D3FEND ‚Äì Detection counterpart to ATT&CK (useful for purple teams).

## II. Initial Access Techniques

### What are common initial access methods?
- Phishing (link, attachment, OAuth consent).
- Drive-by compromise (watering holes, exploit kits).
- Supply chain abuse (malicious updates/scripts).
- Valid accounts (credential stuffing, reused passwords).
- Physical drops (Rogue devices, USB drops).

### What payloads or tools are commonly used?
- Office documents with DDE, OneNote, or macro exploits.
- HTA, ISO, LNK files embedded in ZIPs.
- Custom droppers in Go, Nim, Rust (bypass AV/EDR).
- Payload staging via HTTPS, DNS, or cloud storage.

## III. Command & Control (C2)

### What are common C2 techniques?
- HTTPS over trusted domains (mimic Outlook, Google).
- DNS tunneling (covert channels).
- C2 via cloud (OneDrive, Dropbox APIs).
- Social media-based C2 (Twitter, Reddit).
- Domain fronting (e.g., using Cloudflare or Akamai CDN).

### What tools are used for C2?
- Sliver, Mythic, Cobalt Strike, Havoc, or custom agents.
- Prefer low-signal beacons with jitter, sleep, and obfuscation.
- Use proxy-aware agents in corporate environments.

## IV. Privilege Escalation & Credential Access

### How do adversaries escalate privileges?
- Exploit misconfigured sudoers, token impersonation, UAC bypass.
- Abuse DLL hijacking or custom service installs.
- Access LSASS memory (via Mimikatz, Nanodump, direct syscalls).

### What credential theft techniques are used?
- Mimikatz, Rubeus, SharpDPAPI.
- Dump SAM database / NTDS.dit offline.
- Phishing users for SSO creds or OAuth tokens.
- Pass-the-Hash / Pass-the-Ticket (Kerberos).

## V. Lateral Movement

### How is lateral movement performed?
- WMI, RDP, PsExec, SMB/IPC, WinRM.
- Use Impacket, SharpHound, CrackMapExec.
- Blend in: use legit credentials, match parent-child processes.

### How do you avoid detection during lateral movement?
- Avoid noisy tools (PowerShell, known binaries).
- Use living-off-the-land binaries (e.g., schtasks, msbuild).
- Inject into trusted processes and use direct system calls.

## VI. Defense Evasion

### What are core evasion tactics?
- Process injection (Early Bird, Queue APC, etc.).
- Obfuscated binaries/scripts (Crypters, custom packers).
- Command line evasion (encoded, staged, in-memory).
- EDR bypass using sideloading, AMSI bypass, ETW patching.

### What helps maintain stealth?
- Slow beaconing, long jitter/delay.
- Disable logging or anti-virus safely (if permitted).
- Clean up artifacts (clear logs, delete temp payloads).

## VII. Persistence

### How do attackers maintain persistence?
- Scheduled tasks, Startup folder, WMI persistence.
- Registry keys (Run/RunOnce), login items on macOS.
- Service creation or browser extensions.
- Cloud: OAuth refresh tokens, malicious Azure apps.

## VIII. Exfiltration & Objectives

### How is data exfiltrated covertly?
- Exfil via HTTPS or DNS tunneling.
- Cloud sync abuse (Google Drive, OneDrive).
- Steganography or data embedding in benign files.
- Chunk data, compress, encrypt, and send with subtle C2.

### Common objectives:
- Data theft (PII, source code, credentials).
- Domain dominance (Golden Ticket, DCsync).
- Planting long-term access or backdoors.
- Gaining access to crown-jewel assets (CI/CD, backups).

## IX. Purple Team Execution

### How do red and blue teams collaborate?
- Red shares exact TTPs with blue in real time or post-op.
- Use tools like VECTR, Atomic Red Team, Invoke-ATTACKAPI.
- Purple team goal = enhance detection and response, not ‚Äúwin.‚Äù
- Iterate: simulate > detect > tune > simulate again.

### How are detection gaps identified and addressed?
- Correlate red TTPs with SIEM/EDR logs.
- Use MITRE ATT&CK mapping to identify weak coverage.
- Present in categories: Detected, Partially Detected, Missed.
- Deliver detection engineering recommendations.

## X. Operational Security (OpSec) and Ethics

### What OpSec considerations must be followed?
- Avoid harming production systems (DoS, data corruption).
- Do not trigger security incidents or panic (stealth > chaos).
- Encrypt all payloads and comms (avoid attribution).
- Never leave behind persistent artifacts without consent.

### Ethical & legal guidelines?
- Follow Rules of Engagement (ROE) and get written approvals.
- Avoid sensitive data unless explicitly authorized.
- Report unintended access immediately.
- Be accountable ‚Äî red teaming is high trust.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/PayPal - Offensive Security Engineer/00 - Threat Emulation - Purple Team/Cyber Kill Chain.md
notes.content:
# üìö Offensive Security Engineer Interview Study Guide

## üìå Primary Focus Areas
This guide is designed to help you succeed in a red/purple team interview for an Offensive Security Engineer role. It integrates key content from SANS SEC401, CREST‚Äôs Penetration Testing Guide, Lockheed Martin‚Äôs Cyber Kill Chain, and foundational network infrastructure.

---

## üß† 1. Cyber Kill Chain (Lockheed Martin Model)
Understand and be able to apply the 7-phase kill chain for intrusion modeling and detection/mitigation:

| Phase                      | Description                                   | Example Offensive Tools/Techniques | Defensive Mitigations                |
| -------------------------- | --------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- | ------------------------------------ |
| **Reconnaissance**         | Target selection, harvesting emails, scanning | Google dorking, Maltego, Shodan    | Web analytics, DNS monitoring        |
| **Weaponization**          | Crafting payloads (e.g. macros + exploit)     | MSFVenom, custom droppers          | Endpoint protection, static analysis |
| **Delivery**               | Transmitting the payload (phishing, USB, web) | Email attachments, watering holes  | Proxy filtering, email AV scanners   |
| **Exploitation**           | Triggering the exploit to gain access         | CVE-based RCEs, zero-days          | Patch management, DEP, ASLR          |
| **Installation**           | Establishing persistent access (malware)      | C2 implants, RATs                  | HIDS, behavior monitoring            |
| **Command & Control (C2)** | Remote control over the compromised system    | Cobalt Strike, DNS tunneling       | Firewall ACLs, DNS sinkholes         |
| **Actions on Objectives**  | Achieving attacker goals (e.g. exfiltration)  | Rclone, SMB transfer, mimicry      | Audit logs, DLP, honeytokens         |

---

## üß∞ 2. Network Infrastructure (from SEC401 & Networking PDF)

### üõ°Ô∏è Network Security Fundamentals
- **Defense-in-Depth**: Use multiple layers of controls across network, host, and application.
- **Segmentation**: VLANs, DMZs, and micro-segmentation limit attacker lateral movement.
- **802.1X**: Auth before granting network access, important for secure BYOD/Wi-Fi environments.
- **Topologies**:
  - *Physical*: Actual device connections
  - *Logical*: VLANs, IP addressing, ACLs

### ‚öôÔ∏è Switch/Router Attacks
- **Switch Attacks**: CDP spoofing, MAC flooding, STP/DHCP/VLAN hopping
- **Router Attacks**: Routing table poisoning, DDoS, packet sniffing via misconfig

### üìÅ Protocol Analysis
- Know **TCP/IP**, **ICMP**, **DNS**, **DHCP**, **ARP**, and their abuse (e.g. ICMP tunneling).
- Tools: Wireshark, tcpdump, tshark ‚Äî analyze headers, payloads, anomalies

### üîÅ Network Flow and Data Location
- Understand communication flows: What talks to what, when, and how.
- Identify ‚Äúunintentional cloud‚Äù risks (e.g. Dropbox)
- Always know your high-value assets and choke points

---

## üîì 3. Web Application Security

### üåê Core Concepts
- OWASP Top 10 (2021):
  - A01: Broken Access Control
  - A02: Cryptographic Failures
  - A03: Injection
  - A05: Security Misconfiguration
- Other key issues: SSRF, deserialization, business logic flaws

### üîß Exploitation Techniques
- SQLi, XSS, CSRF, IDOR, JWT abuse
- RCE via template injection (Jinja2, Freemarker)
- SSRF chaining (e.g. to access internal metadata APIs)

### üõ†Ô∏è Testing Tools & Methods
- Burp Suite (Intruder, Repeater, Collaborator)
- FFUF, Dirsearch (discovery)
- Postman + custom scripts for API fuzzing

### üîê Authentication Weaknesses
- Bypass via parameter pollution, JWTs without verification, weak session mgmt
- MFA bypass: Password reset abuse, token reuse

---

## üöñ 4. Threat Emulation Techniques (Red/Purple Team)

### üìç Key TTPs by MITRE ATT&CK Category
- **Initial Access**: Spear phishing, drive-by compromise, supply chain
- **Execution**: PowerShell, WMI, LOLBAS (e.g., mshta.exe)
- **Persistence**: Registry run keys, scheduled tasks, WMI event subs
- **Lateral Movement**: Pass-the-Hash, RDP hijacking, token impersonation
- **Credential Access**: Mimikatz, LSASS dump, DLL injection
- **Defense Evasion**: Signed binary proxy execution, timestomping, AMSI bypass

### ü™ì Testing Frameworks & Labs
- Cobalt Strike, Brute Ratel, Mythic
- Atomic Red Team, Red Canary Simulator, Caldera
- Detection Engineering: Sigma rules, Sysmon config tuning

---

## üßπ 5. Real-World Scenarios to Prepare

### üìå Scenario Walkthroughs
- **‚ÄúWalk us through a red team engagement‚Äù**:
  - Planning: Recon, threat modeling, scoping
  - Execution: Initial access ‚Üí lateral movement ‚Üí objective
  - Reporting: Findings, risk impact, remediations

- **‚ÄúHow do you evade EDR?‚Äù**:
  - Process injection, obfuscated payloads, signed binaries
  - AMSI bypass, in-memory execution (e.g., via PowerShell, C# reflectors)
  - Custom packers and crypters

---

## üß† 6. Mindset, Metrics & Program Maturity

### üìä Maturity Models
- CREST‚Äôs Pen Test Program Maturity: Governance, scope, response
- Metrics: Time to detect/respond, dwell time, cost of breach
- Indicator lifecycle: Reveal ‚Üí Mature ‚Üí Utilize

### üßÆ Soft Skills
- Reporting & communication with both tech and execs
- Collaboration with Blue Team (purple teaming mindset)
- Continual learning & humility

---

## üìö Recommended Resources

### Books
- *Red Team Development and Operations* ‚Äì Joe Vest, James Tubberville
- *The Web Application Hacker‚Äôs Handbook* ‚Äì Dafydd Stuttard
- *Advanced Penetration Testing* ‚Äì Wil Allsopp

### Labs & Practice
- HackTheBox, TryHackMe, RangeForce, Offensive Security Proving Grounds
- [[MITRE ATT&CK]] Navigator for TTP mapping

---

Good luck ‚Äî and remember: every detection teaches you how to be stealthier next time. Every defense teaches you where to strike. üõ°Ô∏è‚öîÔ∏è

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Transport Layer (Layer 4).md
notes.content:
The #[[Network Layer (Layer 3)|Transport Layer]] is the fourth layer in the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model and plays a crucial role in the delivery of data across network connections. It's responsible for providing transparent transfer of data between end systems, or hosts, and is responsible for error recovery and flow control. Here‚Äôs a deeper dive into its functions and characteristics:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **Segmentation and Reassembly**: The Transport Layer takes messages from the Session Layer and splits them into smaller units, known as segments, for easier handling by the network. At the destination, it reassembles these segments into complete messages that are passed to the Session Layer.

2. **Connection Control**: It can be either connection-oriented or connectionless. Connection-oriented transport (like TCP) establishes a connection before transmitting data, ensures all packets arrive in order, and checks for errors. Connectionless transport (like UDP), on the other hand, sends packets without establishing a connection, offering quicker delivery where reliability is less critical.

3. **Error Control**: It is responsible for error-checking and reliable data transfer. This includes detecting corrupted or lost segments and requesting retransmissions if necessary.

4. **Flow Control**: The Transport Layer manages the rate of data transmission between two endpoints to prevent a fast sender from overwhelming a slow receiver.

5. **Port Management**: It uses header information in the packets to direct segments to the correct process on the destination computer by using port numbers.

### Key Protocols
- **[[TCP]] (Transmission Control Protocol)**: A connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable transmission of data. It is used when the accuracy of data delivery is critical, such as in file transfers or web page retrievals.
- **[[UDP]] (User Datagram Protocol)**: A connectionless protocol used for services that require fast, efficient delivery, such as broadcasting video or voice over the internet.

### Examples of Use
- **[[TCP]]** is used for web browsing, email, and file transfers where data integrity and order are crucial.
- **[[UDP]]** is often used for real-time applications like video streaming or online gaming, where speed is more critical than perfect accuracy.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Transport Layer receives data from the Session Layer above it and segments the data for delivery to the Network Layer below, which is responsible for data routing and delivery across network boundaries. The success of the Transport Layer depends significantly on the underlying network's capabilities, specifically in terms of handling congestion and ensuring timely data delivery.

Understanding the Transport Layer is especially important in fields like network engineering and cybersecurity, as it handles the critical tasks of ensuring data integrity and efficient data flow between hosts. This layer's protocols and mechanisms are pivotal in designing networks that are both reliable and secure.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Session Layer (Layer 5).md
notes.content:
The #[[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|Session Layer]] is the fifth layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model, which serves a crucial role in controlling the dialogues (connections) between computers. It establishes, manages, and terminates connections between the local and remote applications. Here‚Äôs a detailed look at the functions and characteristics of the Session Layer:
### Purpose and Functions
1. **Data Translation**: It converts data from the format used by the [[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|application layer]] into a [[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|common format]] at the sending station, and then back from the common format to the application's format at the receiving station. This ensures that data sent from the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another system.

2. **[[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|Data Compression]]**: Reducing the size of the data to be transmitted. [[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|Compression can]] be either lossless, where no information is lost in the compression, or lossy, where some quality of non-critical information is lost to reduce the size of the data further.

3. **Data Encryption and Decryption**: It handles the encryption and decryption needed for secure data transmission. Encryption at this layer ensures that data can be securely transmitted over a network.

### Key Protocols and Standards
- **ASCII** and **EBCDIC** for character encoding.
- **JPEG**, **MPEG**, and other multimedia formats for data compression and encoding.
- **SSL/TLS** for encrypting information that moves across the network.

### Examples of Use
- When accessing a website securely via HTTPS, the SSL/TLS protocols at the [[Presentation Layer (Layer 6)|Presentation Layer]] encrypt the data before it is transmitted over the Internet and decrypt it upon arrival before it is processed by an application.
- When sending an email with attachments, the Presentation Layer might compress the data to facilitate quicker transmission.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Presentation Layer interacts with the Application Layer above it by providing it data in a format that the application can accept, whether it involves translating data between formats, decompressing data, or decrypting information. Below it, the Session Layer establishes, manages, and terminates connections between applications, providing the synchronization and checkpointing needed to support the data exchange processes handled in the Presentation Layer.

In the context of cybersecurity, the Presentation Layer's roles in encryption and data representation are vital. Ensuring that data is encrypted during transmission helps protect sensitive information from interception, and effective data compression can reduce the attack surface by minimizing the amount of data transmitted over the network. Understanding these aspects of the Presentation Layer can significantly enhance security measures and optimize network operations.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Presentation Layer (Layer 6).md
notes.content:
The #[[Session Layer (Layer 5)|Presentation Layer]] is the sixth layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model, sitting just below the [[Session Layer (Layer 5)|Application Layer]] and above the [[Session Layer (Layer 5)|Session Layer]]. This layer is crucial because it acts as the translator or data formatter in the networking process. Here‚Äôs a more detailed look at the functions and characteristics of the Presentation Layer:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **Data Translation**: It converts data from the format used by the application layer into a [[Session Layer (Layer 5)|common format]] at the sending station, and then back from the common format to the application's format at the receiving station. This ensures that data sent from the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another system.

2. **[[Session Layer (Layer 5)|Data Compression]]**: Reducing the size of the data to be transmitted. [[Session Layer (Layer 5)|Compression can]] be either lossless, where no information is lost in the compression, or lossy, where some quality of non-critical information is lost to reduce the size of the data further.

3. **Data Encryption and Decryption**: It handles the encryption and decryption needed for secure data transmission. Encryption at this layer ensures that data can be securely transmitted over a network.

### Key Protocols and Standards
- **ASCII** and **EBCDIC** for character encoding.
- **JPEG**, **MPEG**, and other multimedia formats for data compression and encoding.
- **SSL/TLS** for encrypting information that moves across the network.

### Examples of Use
- When accessing a website securely via HTTPS, the SSL/TLS protocols at the Presentation Layer encrypt the data before it is transmitted over the Internet and decrypt it upon arrival before it is processed by an application.
- When sending an email with attachments, the Presentation Layer might compress the data to facilitate quicker transmission.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Presentation Layer interacts with the Application Layer above it by providing it data in a format that the application can accept, whether it involves translating data between formats, decompressing data, or decrypting information. Below it, the Session Layer establishes, manages, and terminates connections between applications, providing the synchronization and checkpointing needed to support the data exchange processes handled in the Presentation Layer.

In the context of cybersecurity, the Presentation Layer's roles in encryption and data representation are vital. Ensuring that data is encrypted during transmission helps protect sensitive information from interception, and effective data compression can reduce the attack surface by minimizing the amount of data transmitted over the network. Understanding these aspects of the Presentation Layer can significantly enhance security measures and optimize network operations.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/OSI Model.md
notes.content:
---
aliases:
---

[[**OSI Model**]]

7 - Application - Human-computer interaction | HTTP, DNS, FTP, POP3

6 - Presentation - Data representation and encryption | SSH, SSL, IMAP, FTP, JPEG

5 - Session - Connection maintenance | API's, sockets

4 - Transport - End-to-end connections | TCP, UDP

3 - Network -¬† Logical addressing for data path using packets | IP, ICMP, IGMP¬†

2 - Data - Physical addressing, formatting data in frames switch, bridge, ethernet

1 - Physical - transmission of signals, media, or binary raw bits | Physical coax, fiber, wireless

## OSI Model Components

### 7. Application Layer

- **Function**: Facilitates human-computer interaction by providing services to end-user applications.
- **Protocols**: HTTP (Hypertext [[Application Layer (Layer 7)|Transfer Protocol]]), DNS (Domain Name System), FTP (File Transfer Protocol), POP3 (Post Office Protocol version 3).
- **Explanation**: This layer is where applications and services communicate with each other. For example, HTTP is used for web browsing, DNS translates domain names to IP addresses, FTP is used for file transfers, and POP3 is used for email retrieval.

### 6. Presentation Layer

- **Function**: Handles data representation and encryption to ensure that data is in a usable format and secure.
- **Protocols**: SSH (Secure Shell), SSL (Secure Sockets Layer), IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol), FTP, JPEG (Joint Photographic Experts Group).
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for data formatting, compression, and encryption. SSH provides secure remote access, SSL/TLS secures web communications, IMAP is used for email access, and JPEG is a format for image compression.

### 5. Session Layer

- **Function**: Manages connections between applications running on different devices.
- **Protocols**: APIs (Application Programming Interfaces), sockets.
- **Explanation**: This layer establishes, maintains, and terminates connections between applications. APIs and sockets are used to manage these connections, ensuring that data is exchanged correctly between applications.

### 4. Transport Layer

- **Function**: Provides end-to-end connections and ensures reliable data transfer.
- **Protocols**: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol), UDP (User Datagram Protocol).
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for ensuring that data is delivered reliably and in the correct order. TCP provides connection-oriented, reliable service, while UDP offers connectionless, best-effort service.

### 3. Network Layer

- **Function**: Routes data between devices on different networks using logical addressing.
- **Protocols**: IP (Internet Protocol), ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol), IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol).
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for routing data between networks. IP provides logical addressing, ICMP is used for error-reporting and diagnostic functions, and IGMP manages multicast groups.

### 2. Data Link Layer

- **Function**: Provides physical addressing and formats data into frames for transmission over a network.
- **Protocols**: Ethernet, switches, bridges.
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for framing, error detection and correction, and flow control. Ethernet is a common protocol used for local area networks (LANs), and switches and bridges are devices that operate at this layer to forward data frames.

### 1. Physical Layer

- **Function**: Transmits raw bits over a physical medium.
- **Protocols**: Physical coax, fiber, wireless.
- **Explanation**: This layer is responsible for the physical transmission of data. It defines the electrical, mechanical, procedural, and functional specifications for activating, maintaining, and deactivating the physical link between devices. Common media include coaxial cables, fiber optic cables, and wireless communication.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Network Layer (Layer 3).md
notes.content:
The #[[OSI - TCPIP|Network Layer]] is the third layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model and is crucial for managing the delivery of data packets across different networks. It handles the routing of packets, including their forwarding and addressing, to ensure they reach their correct destination. Here's a detailed look at the functions and characteristics of the Network Layer:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **Routing**: The Network Layer is responsible for determining the best path through the network for data to travel from the source to the destination. This involves analyzing the network conditions, the topology, and the routing table to make efficient routing decisions.

2. **Logical Addressing**: It assigns logical addresses (such as IP addresses in the TCP/IP protocol suite) to devices, which helps in identifying the source and destination of the data packets across multiple networks. This addressing helps routers in making decisions about packet forwarding.

3. **Packetizing**: It encapsulates the [[Transport Layer (Layer 4)|transport layer]] data segments into packets, which are known as datagrams in this context. These packets are the units of data that are routed and switched through the network.

4. **Error Handling and Diagnostics**: Implements error reporting mechanisms to manage packet handling problems, such as incorrect routing or delivery failures. Protocols like ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) are used for diagnostic and error-reporting purposes.

### Key Protocols
- **[[IP]] (Internet Protocol)**: The primary protocol used for relaying datagrams across network boundaries. It's used in both IPv4 and IPv6 forms.
- **[[ICMP]] (Internet Control Message Protocol)**: Used for sending error messages and operational information indicating success or failure when IP packets are processed.
- **[[Routing Protocols]]** like RIP (Routing Information Protocol), OSPF (Open Shortest Path First), and BGP (Border Gateway Protocol), which are used to manage routing decisions and share routing information across networks.

### Examples of Use
- **IP Addressing**: Every device connected to the Internet is assigned an IP address. This address is used to ensure that data sent from one device reaches the intended destination device correctly.
- **Routing**: When you send an email, the data packets are sent through various network paths to reach the recipient‚Äôs server; this path determination is handled by the Network Layer.

### Interaction with Other Layers
The Network Layer receives packets from the Transport Layer above it and encapsulates these into packets. Below it, the Data Link Layer is responsible for transmitting the packets over a single link. At the receiving end, the Network Layer ensures that the packets are properly routed to the correct destination application via the transport layer.

In cybersecurity and network design, the Network Layer is crucial because it interfaces different network segments, managing the data traffic and network congestion effectively. Misconfigurations or vulnerabilities at this layer can lead to security risks such as data interception or denial of service, making its understanding essential for securing network infrastructure.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/OSI Model/Application Layer (Layer 7).md
notes.content:
The user's browser (application) makes an HTTP request to a website.

The application prepares the data for transfer, which includes encapsulating the HTTP request with [[OSI - TCPIP|application layer]] headers.

Sure! The #Application Layer is the seventh and topmost layer of the OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model. It serves as the interface between the network services and the applications that users interact with. Here's a closer look at its key functions and characteristics:

### Purpose and Functions
1. **End-User Services**: This layer provides services directly to the end-user applications. It is where communication begins and ends, translating data from a format that applications understand to one suitable for the underlying network processes.
  
2. **Data Access Abstraction**: It abstracts the details of network data structures and the underlying transport layers from the applications. This means that application developers don‚Äôt need to worry about the complexities of the network details.

3. **Session Management**: It manages sessions between networked applications, handling service requests and responses that are sent between peers.

4. **Protocol Implementation**: Various protocols operate at the application layer, including HTTP (for web browsing), FTP (for file transfers), SMTP (for email transmission), and DNS (for domain name resolution).

### Key Protocols
- **[[HTTP]]** (Hypertext [[OSI Model|Transfer Protocol]]): Enables web browsing by communicating between web servers and clients.
- **[[FTP]]** (File Transfer Protocol): Allows users to upload and download files from a remote server.
- **[[SMTP]]** (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol): Facilitates sending emails from clients to servers and between servers.
- **[[DNS]]** (Domain Name System): Translates domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that networks use to locate and identify services.

### Examples of Use
- When you visit a website, your browser uses HTTP to request web pages and resources from web servers.
- When you send an email, your email client uses SMTP to send your message to the recipient through email servers.

### Interaction with Other Layers
While it's the topmost layer from a conceptual standpoint, in practice, applications often bundle several OSI layers together when they communicate over a network. For instance, web browsers incorporate presentation and session layer functions as they manage data encoding and keep track of your interactions with a web server.

The Application Layer interacts with the Presentation Layer directly beneath it, which manages data formats and encryption, ensuring that the data is in a usable format or securely encrypted as needed by the application layer protocol.

Understanding the Application Layer is crucial, especially in fields like cybersecurity and network management, as it directly interacts with user data and services, making it a primary target for security attacks. Knowing how it works can help in designing better security protocols and monitoring tools to protect sensitive information.

import random


```
def main():
    choices = ["rock", "paper", "scissors"]

    while True:
        user_input = input("Choose rock, paper, or scissors (or 'exit' to quit): ").lower()
        if user_input == 'exit':
            break
        if user_input not in choices:
            print("Invalid choice, try again.")
            continue

        computer_choice = random.choice(choices)
        print(f"Computer chose: {computer_choice}")

        if user_input == computer_choice:
            print("It's a tie!")
        elif (user_input == "rock" and computer_choice == "scissors") or \
             (user_input == "paper" and computer_choice == "rock") or \
             (user_input == "scissors" and computer_choice == "paper"):
            print("You win!")
        else:
            print("You lose!")
            
    if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

```
